Are you visiting?’ ‘No, I live here.’ ‘Is your father American?’ ‘No. He came here to write a film script based on a novel he wrote.’ ‘Really? Have I heard of him? What’s his name?’ ‘Rufus Marsh.’ ‘You mean, Tall as the Morning?’ I nodded. ‘I read that book from start to finish.’ She looked at me with new interest, and I realized that people were friendly but only showed real interest when I mentioned Tall as the Morning.'

Text: "‘What have I done?’ Violet Hetherington wondered. She was in a long line at the dock in Southampton, waiting to board the Queen Caroline. The line was spilling out of the area marked ‘Departures’, and no one was moving. Her friend Annie had told her, ‘It’s best to arrive late at the docks. If you get there too early, you’ll just be waiting around.’ Annie, who was married to a diplomat and loved giving advice, was an experienced traveler. But this time, her advice was wrong. After a while, an announcement came over the loudspeakers: there was a ‘breakdown in the computer system.’ This news made the atmosphere among the waiting passengers tense. Some tried to be patient, while others attempted to stay cheerful, but most people became frustrated. They had paid a lot of money for this trip, and many felt it was their last chance for a bit of luxury. The fact that they could not board the ship efficiently did not bode well. Violet felt like leaving. She reached into her bag for her phone and realized it was missing. This was much more annoying than the long wait. It made her feel that going on a cruise was a mistake. Now, she had the added problem of her phone. She couldn’t call the taxi company to see if she had left it in the cab because that number was saved in her phone. This was the very mistake her older son Harry always warned her about. Behind her in the line was a friendly-looking couple. ‘I’m sorry, but I think I left my mobile phone behind. Could I borrow yours to make a quick call?’ Violet used the couple’s phone to call Harry and left a message asking him to ask their neighbor Kristina to check if the phone was left behind. If it wasn’t in her apartment, she would be in trouble since she had no other way to find the numbers she needed in New York. Part of her thought, Thank goodness. But she didn’t tell Harry this. Harry believed that, although he was not much older than his mother, he was much more experienced. Daniel, her younger son, was more understanding of her mistakes, but that was because he made them too. Dan might forget to pass the message to Kristina. Eventually, the line started to move, and Violet was directed to a window where she handed over her travel documents and prepared to board. Her heart sank further when she entered the ship’s foyer, which looked like a not-so-grand hotel trying too hard. There were shiny fake wood panels, fancy chandeliers, polished brass, and carpets that looked like those found in airports. Violet followed the signs to the ‘Elevators’, which were lined with mirrors and packed with tired passengers who might have preferred not to see their reflections. She was squeezed against the side of the lift as it moved up, stopping at each floor to let people out. Finally, on the twelfth floor, she stepped out into freedom. Thankfully, her room had the balcony she had requested. She had been worried about what to say if it didn’t. Ignoring Annie’s advice to wait for a last-minute deal, she had decided to spend the most she could afford to ensure she had a good view of the sea."

Text: 'When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an estate auction, he had no idea he was about to uncover the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof was searching for images for a book about the Portage Park neighborhood in Chicago, USA. Instead, he discovered 30,000 images taken by Maier, a street photographer known for her ability to capture striking images. Since then, Maloof has built a collection of Maier’s life and work. In the attic of his home, he keeps her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, and 100,000 negatives, along with many 8mm movies and audiotapes. One morning, Maloof looked around at all of it and realized he was on the brink of something special, which happened by chance. ‘When I bought all this, I had no idea what it was,’ Maloof said. ‘I’m a third-generation flea market seller and could have easily sold it all to someone else.’ For some time, Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon have been piecing together details of Maier’s life. They reached out to local families who had employed her as a nanny and spoke with staff at the shop where she developed her film. Maier was born in 1926 in New York and spent much of her childhood in France. In 1951, she returned to New York and moved to Chicago in 1956 to work as a nanny. Maier, who was known to be a private person with a unique personality, always carried a camera. She wore oversized coats, wide-brimmed hats, and sturdy shoes. ‘On her day off, the camera would be around her neck first thing in the morning, and we wouldn’t see her again until late at night,’ said Maren Baylaender, whose husband employed Maier to care for his daughter. ‘I remember her as a private person but one who had strong opinions about movies and politics.’ Maier was knowledgeable about theater and films. Although she was not very social, she was not afraid to walk the streets with her camera and talk to people, some of whom she interviewed on audiotape. She seemed to be quite dedicated to her ‘second job’ of documenting the world around her. ‘She was a true artist who followed her dreams,’ said Rydzon. ‘She didn’t let anyone or anything stop her.’ Maier’s work is a pure form of art; she did not create it for commercial reasons. Her images often focus on women, children, the elderly, the poor, and abstract subjects. ‘What is fascinating about Vivian is that she has so many interesting pictures,’ said photography expert Larry Silverman. He sees influences from other photographers in her work and wonders if she developed her own style independently. ‘Was Vivian very skilled, or did she borrow ideas from those before her?’ Maloof often thinks about whether he will ever sort through all the negatives, which he has stored in three tall, fireproof cabinets. Interestingly, he had no real interest in photography until he found Maier’s work. Inspired by her architectural photos, Maloof began to take his own pictures. ‘As I improved as a photographer and revisited her work, I realized that the cityscapes were not what mattered to her. It’s the people, the street scenes, the overall composition,’ he said. ‘There was so much more to this work than I thought, and I realized I was sitting on something more important than I ever imagined. Now our goal is to make her name known. To get Vivian Maier into the history books.'

Text: 'When a novel is called ambitious, it often suggests that it has not fully succeeded. However, this is not the case with Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. I interviewed her in the UK when her book was very successful, and she was at the center of a lot of attention. Despite being in her twenties, she appeared calm. She had just arrived from Germany and was flying back to New Zealand the next day. She shared a story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She pressed her novel against the glass. The official looked at it and asked, “What’s it about?” This is not an easy question for an author. 

The Luminaries takes place in New Zealand during the 1860s, where a series of crimes have occurred, and a group of 12 men has come together to solve them. The plot becomes very complex. Catton intended to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but she found that the past provided more chances for complications and misunderstandings for her characters. At over 800 pages, the book is ‘big by necessity’ because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters a fair chance to shine. 

When I asked her how it feels to be so successful at a young age, she responded thoughtfully. “It’s nice coming from a small country like this, because everyone feels like the success is partly theirs. There’s a strong sense of community at home; I received a lot of support from other people’s grandmas.” She also mentioned that it bothers her when people assume her book is not a serious philosophical work. 

Catton explained that she wanted to write the book in the shape of a spiral, where each part is half the length of the one before it. The story literally speeds up as it progresses. I asked if it matters whether readers notice these patterns. She said, “I wanted to create a book with structural patterns that didn’t matter, but if you cared, you could find them.” 

Despite its unique structure, The Luminaries remains an exciting murder mystery with a captivating plot. Interestingly, Catton said she did not plan the story in advance. “I would try to write myself into a corner and then see how creative I could be in getting out of that situation.” It is clear that one of her goals was to make the book enjoyable for readers. 

We also discussed her love for television dramas, considering how The Luminaries uses cliff-hangers, different viewpoints, and dialogue. I asked if she would be interested in writing for screen. “That could be pretty cool,” she replied. Her enthusiasm was evident, and she laughed softly as she spoke about her work and New Zealand. 

“I always notice how much my imagination changes when I come to Britain. I understand why writers leave New Zealand for more populated places, to experience the energy of other people.” For now, New Zealand will remain her home, and I hope it continues to inspire her for many more novels.'

Text: 'As a boy, Jonny Kinkead spent his time either making things in his dad’s garage or playing with a guitar. For the past forty years, he has been building steel-string acoustic guitars by hand. “I’m still fascinated by the guitar,” he says. “How can two pieces of wood create such a beautiful sound? And how do different types of wood change the sound? It still amazes me.” Jonny learned to play his brother’s guitar when he was eleven. At sixteen, he wanted to learn the bass guitar. “Some people would get a part-time job to save for one,” he says. “But I believed that if you wanted something, you should make it yourself. I studied guitars and learned how different shapes and types of wood affect the sound.” The bass guitar was the first instrument Jonny built from scratch, but he and his brothers had been making model boats and planes for a long time. “We drew designs and then built them, so I was used to the process. My father taught us how to use tools like saws and chisels. I had also been customizing and repairing instruments for my friends.” Jonny’s bass guitar turned out well, but he hadn’t thought about a career in guitar-making yet. “I was also interested in painting and sculpture,” he says. After finishing school, he decided to study architecture at university. “Architecture involves design, which I liked, and being an architect seemed like a good idea,” he remembers. However, halfway through the course, he dropped out. “I was too independent for it,” he says. “But I left with a clearer idea of what I wanted to do. I was still interested in sculpture, but I realized that building guitars is a form of sculpture – one that creates sound. I thought it might be a more practical choice than pure art because you’re making things that people use.” Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he also cleaned windows part-time to earn extra money. The first guitars he sold were priced only to cover the cost of materials, but as he gained a reputation as a skilled guitar-maker, he could charge more. Even now, almost forty years later, Jonny says he is “still just getting by.” He admits he can only make about ten guitars a year, which limits his income. In the early years, he focused on getting known. He attended music festivals most weekends to let musicians try his guitars and talk about him. He also had to learn how to price his instruments, as he didn’t naturally think about such things. Jonny believes it is easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. “When I started, many people thought only American-made acoustic guitars were good,” he says. “UK-made guitars weren’t considered real, even though we have always had excellent instrument-making courses and the skills have remained strong. Now, our hand-made guitars have the reputation they deserve.” Jonny says valuable skills can be learned in classes, and he thinks new instrument-makers should take the available courses. However, he also believes there is no substitute for learning through experience. “You should look at other instruments, see what works and what doesn’t, and try different things,” Jonny says. “If you make the back too thin or too thick, it won’t sound good. If you learn from someone else, you may only learn one method, but if you teach yourself, like I did, you learn everything.”'

Text: 

When discussing English conversation, we often start with the weather. Following this tradition, I will mention the well-known saying by the eighteenth-century writer Dr. Johnson: "When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather." This statement is still true today, just as it was over two hundred years ago. However, many people stop here or struggle to explain why the English seem so focused on the weather. They make a mistake by thinking that when we talk about the weather, we are genuinely interested in it. 

For example, the American writer Bill Bryson points out that English weather is not very interesting. He notes that in England, we do not experience extreme weather events like tornadoes or blizzards, which are common in other places. In response, the English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman argues that English weather is indeed interesting. He believes that the English fascination with the weather is not about strong feelings; rather, it is about its unpredictability. He says that while we may not have tropical storms, living on the edge of an ocean means we can never be sure what the weather will be like.

From my research, I believe that both Bryson and Paxman miss the main point: our conversations about the weather are not really about the weather itself. Instead, talking about the weather is a way for English people to connect with each other. For instance, phrases like "Nice day, isn’t it?" or "Ooh, isn’t it cold?" are not genuine questions about the weather; they are common greetings or ways to start a conversation. 

In this sense, English weather talk is similar to "social grooming" among monkeys, who spend time grooming each other to bond socially. There are specific situations where weather talk is used. Some writers claim that the English talk about the weather all the time, but this is not accurate. In reality, there are three main contexts for weather talk: as a simple greeting, as a way to break the ice before discussing other topics, or as a fallback topic when conversations stall and there is an awkward silence. 

This does lead to a lot of weather talk, which makes it seem like English people are obsessed with it. An English conversation might start with a weather greeting, move to some ice-breaking weather talk, and then return to weather talk during pauses. This is why people from other countries, and even some English commentators, think that the English are preoccupied with the weather.

Alice Leader stood in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain, trying to explain to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds what an amazing engineering achievement it was for the Romans to build something 120 km long and 5 meters high about 1900 years ago. The students were interested in this trip, choosing it over exciting tours to Spain, Greece, or France. However, they wanted to know why the wall was built, and Alice felt her answers were not good enough. Unable to find a suitable historical novel to help explain life at the Wall during Roman times, she decided to write one herself. After retiring from teaching for 31 years, Alice began her new career as an author in 2001. 

After a successful teaching career, Alice felt she was taking a big step into the unknown. She said, “Teaching is like acting; it’s a performance every day and very physically demanding. Writing is exciting and a bit scary, but it’s not as exhausting. My former teaching colleagues envy me because I still connect with children through my stories.” Alice’s main goal for her novels is to fill a gap in children’s fiction today. “Much of the young adult fiction now focuses on negative experiences. It is well written,” she added quickly, “but a lot of it is dark reality, or it’s total fantasy, like Harry Potter. My books are neither.”

Alice always tried to teach English and History together, such as lessons about ancient Greece alongside the novel Tale of Troy. She is motivated by her love for children. “I’m very interested in the moment when a child goes from being bored to interested, and then from not understanding to understanding. I love having bored children because that’s when the challenge begins. It’s up to me to make it work at that point.” She sees her writing as an extension of her teaching. 

Although she was inspired to write her first novel because she saw a gap in the market, the idea also came as her two sons were leaving home, and after her head teacher suggested she would enjoy a creative writing course. Alice was surprised. “I had been teaching for 25 years. She said it would be good for me, but I didn’t want to spend my summer doing a course I didn’t think I needed.” Before she could join the course, she had to send the tutors her best piece of fiction, which she learned about just days before leaving. “I sat down at the computer and quickly created a story about a Roman couple and their baby-to-be.” Three hours and 30 pages later, she sent it in and was accepted right away. 

During the course, the other students reviewed her work as it developed, gave her great feedback, and encouraged her to publish it. With only 8,000 report cards as proof of her writing ability besides that one story, she asked her school’s head teacher for a year off to write her first novel. It helped that her husband, Zachary Leader, is a critic and editor; his help in editing the novel was crucial. Alice said, “My mother-in-law thinks we’re now rival authors, but I believe we complement each other. He works with what I’ve written – he reads a chapter and changes the sentence structure, and if it’s not working, he suggests different words. My instinct is to keep adding more scenes. That’s the difference between a fiction writer and an editor or critic.”

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company challenged brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to participate in a special race. This race would have Jonny racing in a car on the roads, while Alistair would race on a mountain bike across the countryside. The race took place in the beautiful and rugged Yorkshire Dales in northern England. 

“I’m looking forward to it,” Jonny said as they prepared to start. “I’ve never done anything like this before; it’s exciting! The views here are beautiful, and it’s very cold, so I’ll be warm in the car.” Alistair, dressed in full winter cycling gear, was also eager. “To be honest,” he said, “I’ve seen Jonny drive before, so I’m not sure he’ll make it. I might stop for a cup of tea halfway up.”

The race began at Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and would finish at Fleet Moss, Yorkshire’s highest road, which is about 350 meters high. This would be easy for the car, but Alistair faced a steep climb right from the start. After a quick handshake, they were off. Alistair sped away on his bike, heading straight up the hill, while Jonny got into his car and started driving. The question was, who would reach the finish line first?

Jonny’s confidence quickly faced a challenge. Just 15 seconds into his drive, he encountered a large tractor blocking the road. “Welcome to Yorkshire,” he complained to the cameraman in the car. After getting past the tractor, Jonny continued driving, while Alistair struggled with the steep slope. A few miles in, he had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, passing walls and fences. Sheep watched curiously as the Olympic champion kept moving at a steady pace. Finally, he reached the top. With the sun shining and open land ahead, he began to pick up speed.

In the car, Jonny faced another challenge. The narrow roads in this part of Yorkshire were not built for fast driving. He carefully navigated a tight corner and drove through a stream that had formed on the road. Once past the last village, he was on a straight path to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close the other was. As Jonny accelerated down the final stretch to Fleet Moss, Alistair was racing across his last field and back onto the road, approaching the finish from the other side. 

With his head down and legs pumping, Alistair reached the finish line and suddenly hit the brakes. He looked up and asked the crowd, “Is he here?” When they replied no, he raised his arms in celebration, shouting, “Yes!” Moments later, Jonny’s car arrived, and he stepped out. “Well done,” he said, feeling disappointed. “I’m gutted.”

Text: 'The silence is what you notice when you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass; you toss it up to serve; you hit it and hear the echo of your own shot. The well-kept grass, the rich history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds all create a special atmosphere that protects you from the outside world. The quiet of Centre Court helps my game. What I struggle with most in a tennis match is to focus only on the game and the point I’m playing. The silence is broken by loud applause and cheers when a point ends. I hear them, but it feels distant. I don’t realize that there are fifteen thousand people watching me closely, or that millions are watching around the world as I play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I had always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my coach, taught me from a young age that this was the most important tournament. By the time I was 14, I was sharing with my friends my dream of playing there one day and winning. Before 2008, I had played and lost to Federer twice – in the final the year before and the year before that. The loss in 2006 was not too hard. I was just happy to have made it that far at twenty. Federer won easily, more easily than if I had believed in myself more. But my loss in 2007 was devastating. I knew I could have played better; it was not my skill that failed me, but my mindset. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room after that match. Losing always hurts, but it hurts more when you have a chance and lose it. Toni, who is usually very tough, surprised me by saying there was no reason to cry and that there would be more Wimbledons and finals. I told him he didn’t understand; I felt this was my last chance to win. I know how short a professional athlete's career is, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment matters, but some moments matter more than others, and I had let an important one slip away in 2007. There was nothing Toni could do to ease my pain. Yet he turned out to be right. Another chance came in 2008, just one year later. I was confident I had learned from my defeat; this time, my mindset would be strong. The best sign that I was ready was my belief that I would win. At dinner with family and friends the night before the final, we avoided talking about the match. I didn’t tell them not to mention it, but they understood that I was already mentally preparing for the game. From that moment until the match started, that mental space was mine alone.'

Text: 'In early April 1957, a young and idealistic Englishwoman arrived in Africa. In her first letter home, she wrote, “I am living in the Africa I have always longed for.” This woman was Jane Goodall, and she would spend most of her life in Africa as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. In 1963, the National Geographic Society in Britain helped make Jane Goodall famous by publishing articles and making documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. Her fame grew with her own writing, including popular children’s books and the 1971 bestseller *In the Shadow of Man*, which has been translated into 47 languages and is still available today. Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, second only to Marie Curie. However, her fame sometimes overshadows her real achievements. Many articles and interviews tell her life story, but they often focus on sentimental aspects. She has been portrayed as a little girl seeking adventure, a privileged woman wanting to live with wild animals, and a determined feminist in a male-dominated world. These portrayals can diminish her true contributions. 

Based on the number of academic references to her research, the success of her students in biology, and the extensive data from her forty-year study, Jane Goodall should be recognized as a pioneering zoologist. More simply, she opened our eyes to the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees. Before Goodall's work, people misunderstood the dangers of wild chimpanzees. No one knew that chimpanzees ate meat or that they used tools, like humans. We did not realize that chimpanzees share similar emotions with us or that their social structures are surprisingly similar to ours. We also learned that chimpanzee communities in Africa have unique cultural traditions. Goodall’s book, *The Chimpanzees of Gombe* (1986), is the most important work in this field and serves as the first encyclopedia for chimpanzee research. Her long-term study of wild chimpanzees in Gombe State, Nigeria, is considered one of the great scientific achievements of the Western world. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals, and since chimpanzees are our closest relatives, she also changed how we view ourselves.

Even as a child, there were signs of the biologist Jane Goodall would become. One clear example happened in the autumn of 1939 when she was just five years old. One day, Jane disappeared, and her family called the police to help find her. After a frantic search, she reappeared alone, with straw in her hair and clothes. Her mother asked, “Where have you been?” Jane explained that she wanted to know how hens lay eggs. To find out, she had crawled into a henhouse, hidden in the straw, and stayed still for five hours until a hen laid an egg. This moment can be seen as the start of her journey as a biologist.'

Text: 'In our first hour-long conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me using the voice of a playful 8-year-old boy, the boy’s tired mother, a funny elderly Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to viewers of children’s TV shows and cartoons, as well as people who have seen computer programs about health and safety. “I just did a voiceover about back injuries,” she says, “so I had to quickly learn how to pronounce many medical terms.” Shirley explains what it takes to do voiceovers. “Many actors, even well-known ones, think they can do funny voices, and many probably can,” she says. “But there’s more to it. You have to bring the script to life for an audience that can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many famous people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions because of their fame, but often they don’t get the roles because they are too used to acting with their whole bodies.” 

After school, Shirley joined a drama course with the goal of having a standard acting career. During the course, she occasionally worked singing jingles for TV ads. “One day,” she says, “the man who ran the recording studio suggested I try out for the part of a rabbit in a cartoon soundtrack. It seemed silly – I hadn’t studied drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and, surprisingly, got a major role.” Shirley discovered she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. “Things just happened for me,” she says. “In my second film, I was lucky enough to play the main character – and her brother and mother.” 

Adult female actors are often asked to provide the voices for small boys and girls. Their voices are lighter than those of male actors, and hiring child performers involves complex procedures and many forms, which production companies prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create the right sounds from the back of her throat, and to avoid always sounding like the same child, she collects new voices while watching children’s TV. Cartoons are the best part of a job that includes a variety of work, from educational videos to vacuum cleaner ads. “Those are tough because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my years in this profession help,” she says. “They’ve taught me that the trick is to smile while you talk – that makes your voice sound bright and cheerful. When I have days doing animation work, it feels like a holiday; the interaction with other actors makes a big difference.” 

The competition for work is strong, and a good showreel – a recording that shows what the artist can do – is very important. “It’s definitely worth investing in a strong showreel,” Shirley says. “There are agencies that specialize in helping voiceover artists create them.” She believes she has reached her position – near the top of her field – through determination as much as talent. “Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to all the film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or just practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.” For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley recommends attending “specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.” She also believes a passion for human sound is essential, describing herself as obsessed with voices and, in a way, becoming the characters she performs. “If I’ve been in the studio doing a specific kind of American voice, for example, it can take over me and I’ll be speaking like that for hours, maybe even days afterwards,” she says. “My children have grown up used to their mom talking in completely different voices.”'

Text: 'People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This is understandable because cartooning is a job many dream about as children, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually give up these childhood dreams and think about more practical careers, like being a tax lawyer or making car parts. The idea that you can earn a living by drawing simple pictures, like those in high school notebooks, seems silly at first. Yet, some people do just that. 

Not everyone becomes a cartoonist in the same way, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, I had a typical childhood for a cartoonist, with a love for comic strips, contributing to school publications, and being known as 'the kid who draws.' I studied graphic design in college and, after graduating, I showed my illustrations to different companies. I was fortunate to find someone at a newspaper who needed political cartoons about local issues. I created a few ideas, and they bought them; within a few months, I was earning enough to support myself.

You don’t need much to become a cartoonist. You don’t need a university degree, a lot of money, or even to be a great artist. You just need your mind, your hand, and something to make marks with. However, if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as there are teachers. While the technical skills needed are low, it is still a challenging job. No one should try to become a cartoonist unless they feel they cannot do anything else. It is much easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and allows time for family, home repairs, and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better chance you have of making a living from your art. I have created political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I have also worked as a writer, caricaturist, and designer. I accept all kinds of work because you can learn a lot, even from jobs you don’t really want to do. It helps to be intelligent, well-read, and curious about the world around you.

What about the business side of being a cartoonist? There was a time when many cartoonists could find regular jobs with different newspapers and magazines. But those days are fading. For most people today, cartooning is an entrepreneurial activity, meaning you not only have to create the work but also sell it. The more comfortable you are with this process, the more successful you will be. 

I have seen many cartoonists with average creative skills but excellent business skills do much better than those who are very talented but lack other skills. It surprises me how often I meet people who have never sold a cartoon and are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried that they won’t even let others see their work! Legally, to protect your work, you just need to draw a small ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ circle it, and write your name and the date next to it. But realistically, it is more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it is not a disaster – it could actually be a lucky break!'

Text: 'Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and cleaning out my things. Among other items, I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad had given me for my 16th birthday. It was a sleek, black guitar made in Japan. I usually hate getting rid of even useless items, so why did I want to throw this one away? I took it to the dump and was about to leave it on a pile of trash when a young man approached me, looking confused. “You’re not really going to throw that away, are you?” he asked. I told him I was, and I started to feel regret. He asked if he could have it, and I said ‘Yes’. We then went our separate ways. In the days and years that followed, I felt a deep sadness for what I had done. A few months ago, I opened an email that changed my life. I remembered a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it ten years later in a fish he was eating. That’s how I felt when I clicked on an email from someone I didn’t know, a guitar dealer and restorer named Keith Rushton. He wrote, “I’ve got your electric guitar.” It had been bought and sold many times since the young man at the dump took it from me. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back of the guitar. He realized it was probably out of date but used my name to find me online. He eventually contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was overwhelmed with emotion. I would have given Keith anything he wanted, but his price was very fair. I had forgotten that my dad always put name-and-address stickers on my things, including my guitar. My dad would have laughed at this strange situation! My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar because it was popular in the 1970s. I loved the sound of it: calming and gentle, and it was easier for beginners than the violin. However, I didn’t make much progress, so I switched to the electric guitar and played simple songs. This was also the time of punk music, when people who couldn’t play well could still be rock stars. When I took my old guitar out of the box that Keith sent me, I suddenly remembered my birthday in 1978 when my smiling parents gave it to me. Holding it again, it felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I sat down to play, but then I wanted to stand up and put a strap over my shoulder because electric guitars are played that way. My fingers knew what to do. I couldn’t have drawn a diagram for the chords I wanted to play, but my hands just moved into position. My middle-aged fingers felt the familiar pain of pressing down the strings to play a chord. The electric guitar is not really a solo instrument. Now that I’m learning it again, I think I’ll need to form a band. My son is learning the saxophone; maybe we can play together. Or perhaps there are others my age who have had a similar experience. We could call ourselves ‘The Regainers’!'

Text: 

Recently, there has been much discussion about sleep. When I wrote the book *Insomniac*, which focuses on people who struggle with sleeplessness, I felt like I was one of the few warning about the dangers of not getting enough sleep and how it affects our minds, bodies, and emotions. Anyone who has trouble sleeping will tell you that sleep is essential for our mental, physical, and social health. Interestingly, those who find it hardest to sleep often understand its importance the most. It is encouraging that sleep is finally receiving the attention it deserves. However, I wonder about dreams. There hasn’t been much talk about them. We are losing our dreams all the time. When you wake up early due to an alarm, you miss out on the last hour or two of sleep, which is mostly REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep, the stage where we have the most dreams. Our most vivid and powerful dreams happen during REM sleep just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep time in REM, meaning a person who lives to be 90 years old will spend around six or seven years in this stage. When researchers prevent people from experiencing REM sleep, they find that the next night, the amount and intensity of REM sleep increases to make up for it. This suggests that dreams serve a purpose. 

When researchers discovered REM sleep in 1953, many agreed with the psychologist Sigmund Freud, who believed that understanding dreams was key to understanding our minds. However, later research did not support this idea, and the focus shifted to the physical reasons behind dreams rather than the psychological ones. Currently, there is little agreement among dream researchers, according to Harvard sleep scientist Robert Stickgold. 

Dreams are significant. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School shared a study showing that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams much better than others. He concluded that the use of dreams increases with a person's interest in creativity. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection to their dreams, as film is one of the most dream-like forms of human expression. However, I wondered if only creative people benefit from their dreams. Don’t all professions, like teaching, software design, and politics, require creative thinking? 

Stickgold explains that dreams help us connect ideas in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from our past and present to create new associations. Dreams may help us discover new patterns and combinations that challenge our usual ways of thinking. For instance, Stickgold found that when people are awakened from REM sleep and asked to respond to a specific word, their answers are more original than when they are woken from other sleep stages. They tend to "ignore the obvious" and combine ideas in unexpected ways, which is a form of creativity. Personally, I find that I write better after experiencing intense dreams. Even a difficult dream, or one that I can barely recall, seems to inspire my thoughts. On those days, words and images flow so quickly that I can hardly keep up with my typing. I don’t fully understand how this happens, but it does seem effective. 

Creativity is not just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world, and everyone needs their brains to function well. We must think creatively and flexibly as we interact with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why dreaming is important.

Text: 'Twenty years ago, Susie Ray left London to move to a small coastal town in south-west England. When you enter her studio, which has a stunning view of the sea, you see several empty frames on the walls, along with happy photos of her two daughters. As a leading artist in the copyist art movement, who can recreate the beauty of early 20th-century impressionist paintings and the brilliance of 16th-century Caravaggio portraits, it seems unusual that she has no works of her own displayed. “I don’t keep any,” Susie says with a shrug. “As soon as I finish them, they go.” The reason is that Susie is in high demand. Over her 30 years as a copyist artist, she has painted many famous artists' works, including Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her reproductions are so accurate that art experts often mistake them for the originals. While the originals can sell for millions at auctions, her copies sell for a few hundred pounds to £12,000, depending on how much time she spends on them. Susie does not reveal most of her clients, even when asked, but they include galleries and private collectors. While many collectors truly love art, some are more interested in status. One celebrity enjoys showing off his ‘Van Gogh’ painting, which is actually a ‘Susie Ray Van Gogh’. “Many famous people pass off my copies as originals,” she says. “That’s their choice.” Some collectors save on insurance by keeping the original in a bank safe and displaying Susie’s copy instead. Susie has always been honest about her work. When she copies an old masterpiece, she aims to make it look as real as possible, believing that doing a poor job would disrespect the original artist. However, she does sign her name on the back of the canvas. Selling a copy as the real thing is illegal, and although she knows people who have profited from that, she has never been tempted. Those who create fakes often face serious consequences. She mentions that she isn’t wealthy and has faced challenges, but her situation is more stable now, and it wouldn’t be wise to risk her reputation with collectors and artists. Susie didn’t always work as a copyist. After earning her art degree, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden for several years, earning very little. Looking back, she sees it as valuable experience that sparked her love for plants, even though it was hard to make ends meet. She explains that she had to be very precise and get things right on the first try. She has no regrets about that time but is happy to have found a more financially rewarding career. When younger artists seek her advice, she emphasizes the importance of learning to draw accurately. She also highlights how much she has studied to master her craft. Her training allows her to create everything from plant drawings to perfect copies of 15th-century masterpieces and 20th-century abstract art, although she now focuses on French impressionists, particularly Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. Susie notes that many people think modern art is simple, almost like child’s play. However, she believes that while impressionists painted quickly and freely, they were also very careful, and achieving that balance is quite challenging. Given her talent, it seems strange that Susie doesn’t create her own original works. Isn’t art about self-expression? Could a Susie Ray original be worth more than a copy? She explains that her work is the result of years of training and dedication, and she earns a good living from it. She has tried creating her own art before, such as oil paintings of fishing nets, but they ended up looking like photographs—acceptable, but nothing special. Perhaps it’s like living on plain food after enjoying meals prepared by a top chef. What stands out about Susie is her perfectionism.'

Text: 'During her racing days, Ellen MacArthur cared most about the sea and being the fastest on it. This passion started in her childhood. She had a unique bond with the boats that took her around the world; they felt like one entity. When she returned to land, everyday life seemed unimportant. People were too curious about her race, and she quickly wanted to be back on the ocean, challenging nature, even in places that had almost defeated her. After finishing second in the Vendée Globe, a solo, non-stop round-the-world race, she took me into the small, stuffy cabin of her boat, Kingfisher. There, she showed me what had been her home, workspace, and survival area for 94 days. She explained how carefully she planned her supplies, counting every item, even the number of kitchen paper rolls she would need. Preparation was crucial, she said. She proudly displayed her unappealing stock of foil-wrapped, freeze-dried food, a small gas stove, and neatly organized medical supplies and rations. Her attention to detail was as impressive as her sailing skills. The boat was her entire world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it. Now, she views the world as a boat: a small, beautiful, fragile thing with limited resources. Her perspective changed during a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey on albatrosses. ‘It made me stop and think. It gave me space to see things differently,’ she said. The many abandoned whaling stations served as a warning to her. ‘It felt like we just took what we wanted and moved on. That’s what we do.’ When I arrived at Ellen’s office, she was finishing a heated conference call. She then explained why we must act now to protect the planet. ‘Coal, oil, and gas are no longer being made. They are precious resources we have only once. We need to find ways to use them wisely. At first, my message was negative – to use less – but I realized there is a more positive way to think about it.’ Now, she focuses on reusing materials, passionately discussing things like reusable industrial carpet tiles. For the past three years, she has been visiting factories, mines, and power stations, speaking to government and business leaders about our dependence on non-renewable resources. ‘I will never be an expert,’ she says. ‘But I am like a sponge. I love absorbing information. The current situation is something I cannot ignore. Compared to sailing, this feels less selfish. It’s about finding how my voice can be most helpful. It truly matters.’ She also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that works with businesses and schools to inspire young people to rethink and redesign a sustainable future. ‘I do miss the adventure of being at sea,’ she admits. ‘It defines who I am. You feel connected to everything around you. There’s no time to feel lonely. You focus on records, practical matters, and survival. My new message will never be as simple as saying: “I’m going to be the fastest around the world.” I may have been the fastest, but this work is more important than anything I’ve ever done.’

Text: 'Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become one of the most famous teenagers of his time. He hopes to inspire other kids to explore the outdoors, especially since many young people spend a lot of time on computers and video games. Jordan's climbing team includes his father, Paul, and mother, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero,' and climbing Everest is just part of their goal. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to have climbed the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Very few people achieve this before the age of thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of them and might complete the challenge before he turns 20.

I spoke to several experienced Everest climbers, and none thought it was a good idea to take a 13-year-old up the world's highest mountain. They agreed that a young climber might have the physical strength, but they were unsure if a teenager would be emotionally strong enough. They also questioned whether a young person could have enough experience to make the right decisions needed for such a dangerous climb. The Romeros have heard these opinions before. Paul says, 'I know there is criticism, but I can't focus on it – we have so much to do. I think about possible problems, of course. Karen and I consider the risks all the time, but we believe our experience as climbers will help. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He is becoming strong and mature.'

I also wonder about Jordan's reasons for wanting to climb. Is this just an ambitious father pushing his own love for adventure too far? Paul insists, 'This project isn’t about me trying to gain fame through my son’s achievements. At first, Jordan thought about doing it later in life, but we discussed it and decided: ‘Why not now?’ We talk to him regularly to ensure he still wants to do it.' When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, 'I just focus on achieving my goal.'

In the past, few people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Today, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a record-setting challenge. The more exciting the record, the more interest it creates. This puts Jordan in a difficult position. We often say that achieving goals can take away from the enjoyment of the experience, but if Jordan wants to inspire others, he has to engage with the media. This means blogging, posing for photos, and giving interviews. He needs to offer something impressive, like climbing Everest. Paul adds, 'If Jordan comes home tomorrow and says he’s done with mountain climbing and wants to play basketball instead, we will stop this project and go to the gym.'

Text: 'When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it’s likely they are not listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they usually don’t know who he is. I have just started a music degree, but my classmates know as little about classical music as most people our age. If you don’t know who composed the music, you probably don’t own any of their recordings. This situation must be disappointing for classical music lovers. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music events, and the average classical recording sells only about 300 copies. I find that hard to believe. So, why is there less interest in a type of music that has existed for centuries? Older people often blame our love for TV and video games for this decline, but I don’t think that’s the reason. The truth is that classical music doesn’t attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the ones most likely to buy music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who enjoy classical concerts, but they are rare. Even though I play in an orchestra, I’m not a big fan of classical music. I like many styles, but based on what’s on my computer, my classical music listening is probably close to that 3% figure. 

So, why don’t teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its many mood changes, can be challenging for us. We prefer fast talking, fast playing, and fast thinking. Experts say we struggle to pay attention for more than three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but just right for a pop song. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while understanding classical music takes time and focus. The themes in pop music are also more relatable than a long classical piece without lyrics. Classical music is powerful, but it often doesn’t address the issues that matter to teenagers. 

The way we listen to music has changed too. In the past, families would gather to make music together, and playing an instrument was highly valued. Now, you can find any music online, but classical music is rarely part of our daily lives. When was the last time you heard classical music playing in a store? One of my teachers says that audiences at classical concerts have increased recently. Maybe, but I doubt many of those new attendees are teenagers. In my orchestra, we perform classical music in various places, but when I look at the audience, I mostly see older people. I don’t know why classical concerts attract more middle-aged people, but I do know that if your parents love something, you often want to avoid it. 

Some people blame schools for teenagers’ lack of interest in classical music, but many kids are eager to play classical music in their school orchestras. They come early to practice and stay late to rehearse. They enjoy classical music when they perform, but it’s not their preferred music otherwise. The two activities have become separate. When we want to relax, we usually choose pop music.'

Bonnie Wyndham stepped out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. “I’ll make you regret I came here,” she said to the school, with a smile. Her mother was getting out of the other side and didn’t hear her, but Bonnie wouldn’t have minded if she had. Her mother understood how Bonnie felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was an unusual school, with buildings scattered among the trees on a hillside; it was quite confusing at first. Then she noticed the signs on a post: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… “Riding centre,” Bonnie said, suddenly interested. “Headmaster’s study,” her mother replied. “This way.” Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path that curved between the trees. “I wish you’d walk next to me instead of following me like a dog,” Mrs. Wyndham said tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to do so. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his study, while Bonnie waited outside the door. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. “Why should I just sit here?” she thought. “I’ll be kicked out soon anyway, so why not get it over with?” She left the building and headed towards the riding centre, following the sign. There was a charming old building for the horses and a large indoor riding area. Bonnie looked around, but there was no one in sight. She approached the horses with a sense of respect. The horses were well cared for, and she noticed that immediately. Almost every stall was occupied, and she walked along, carefully observing each horse. “I know what you’re doing here,” she said to a small pony, gently touching its nose. The next horse caught her attention. “But aren’t you the best of them all!” she exclaimed. He was brown with a bit of white. He looked lively, which Bonnie liked. “I feel like we’ve met before,” she said, stroking his neck. “In my dreams, I was riding you to victory in a big competition…” Above the stall was his name: Maverick. Suddenly, she couldn’t resist the urge to ride him. “I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle. It can’t be far.” Bonnie was thrilled to find that the room with the riding equipment was unlocked. Lost in the joy of putting a saddle on Maverick, she forgot all about her mother and the headmaster. When she climbed onto the big horse outside, she felt like a queen, in control of everything she could see. Her nickname at her old school had been Queen Bee, and she laughed happily as she remembered it. “You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick,” she said with admiration. “I’m serious, I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else.” She nudged him into a walk, then into a trot. “If I stay here, I think we could be great friends,” she said. She rode around the paddock. The rhythm was exciting, with a light breeze brushing past her cheek. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she felt sure he would jump well.

Text: 'I have met Cody Simpson before and have always admired his quiet confidence. The 15-year-old Australian has already released many successful songs. So how did a relaxed surfer end up performing on stage in front of thousands of fans? “I first picked up a guitar when I was six years old and started writing songs when I was seven,” Cody says, remembering how it all started. “But I was swimming and surfing every day. Those activities were more important to me back then; I had a full life and many things to do. When I was 13 and in high school, I posted a few videos online.” These videos changed everything. He began by sharing a video of himself and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans commented online, asking for more videos. So Cody, who had recorded more at home, was happy to share them. The responses were overwhelming. Cody was also a talented swimmer. He trained hard with top coaches and focused on improving his sport. But then record labels contacted him, and he faced a tough choice: stay in Australia and keep swimming, or take a big risk by signing a deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the leap. “It was very hard for me – especially at such a young age – to choose a career. Can you imagine being 12 or 13 years old and trying to decide what you want to do for the rest of your life?” He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the States. “It surprised most people. I’m kind of the quiet kid,” he says, recalling their shocked faces. “I’m very modest, and I think it’s important to stay that way in this crazy industry.” So Cody packed his bags and traveled with his family across the world, giving up one dream to pursue another. Although his family stays out of the spotlight and is not directly involved in his career, they support him from behind the scenes. Cody believes it’s important to have a close circle of good people around you to keep you grounded. Of course, everyone has moments of doubt. “Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, ‘How does my decision affect my little brother and sister?’ My little brother is eight years old, and he’s traveling the world, doing school on the road; he doesn’t have a normal life,” Cody admits. “I worry about how that affects him, but my family always reassures me that they support me in everything I do.” Success in any career comes from being willing to say ‘yes’ to your big opportunity, even when it’s a bit scary. “It all happened so fast and unexpectedly,” Cody says. “Now, I’m going to countries I never thought I’d visit and playing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans – it’s something many people dream of achieving. But I know it won’t last forever.”'

Text: 

I jumped out of bed, pulled back a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked down at the river bend. A new crack in the ice sparkled in the morning sunlight. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the wall of sandbags, which were there to protect the buildings from flooding as the river ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting them into place. Last week, I had worked with most of the town’s adults for long hours, showing that I could handle the job. My grandfather didn’t seem to notice much. With one hand still on the curtain, I looked at the half-mile stretch of steaming black water created by the release pipe from the wood processing factory in Milltown. There were fragile ice shelves on either side, and the dark open water was followed by solid ice downstream. As I took off my pajamas and reached for my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the far side of the river. I didn’t recognize him. I frowned. Amazingly, he was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the water warmed by the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and grabbed my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for my lucky chain – a silver chain my famous grandfather once brought back from an expedition in South America. This chain is much more special to me than having a famous grandfather, and only he, my mom, and I know about it. I also have the actual diary he kept on that journey, which I keep under my pillow and read before I sleep. I touched the chain again and went to the kitchen. 

“Good morning, Rex,” my mom smiled at me as I took a banana from the counter. “You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training session. Be careful.” 

“Thanks, Mom.” I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into my tall grandfather as he stepped out of his bedroom. 

“Can’t you watch where you’re going?” he shouted. “Where are you going?” 

“Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.” It was obvious from my wetsuit, and he had seen me in my kayak every morning. Grandpa is Grandpa, and I try to ignore it when he gets angry, but it has been harder lately. 

“What’s the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,” he said. For a moment, his harsh words hit me hard. But I took a deep breath and counted to three in my head. He walked down the hall and slammed the bathroom door. My mom came in with a sympathetic smile. 

“Don’t mind him. He’s…” 

“...not himself right now,” I finished for her. I held back from saying he had always been that way. But like my mom, I try to be understanding. When I was a child, he was my hero – ever since he first showed me photos of himself in National Geographic magazine. Those old photos still hang framed on his bedroom wall, above his dusty medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own growing collection of trophies to look at, and maybe one day, my own face in National Geographic. Still, a part of me wants to stay loyal to him, this grumpy old man. 

My mom smiled. “At least he’s coming out of his bedroom more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination to keep going, even on these cold days!” 

I smiled back at her as I peeled my banana. “It’ll be warmer in South America,” I said. “If I find sponsors for my expedition.” 

She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I finished my banana and went downstairs. Stepping into the backyard, I hurried towards the boathouse.

Text: 'Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. “Come with me,” she said. Jess followed her into the study, where on the table, leaning against the wall, was an unframed painting. It was clearly one of Grandpa’s works, but it looked different from anything he had done before and was obviously unfinished. “Do you know anything about this?” Mum asked. Jess shook her head. “I’ve never seen it before. I didn’t know he was working on anything.” Jess looked closely at the painting. There was a river that took up most of the scene; it was not a river she recognized and might not even be real, just a fantasy river. The painting was strange and beautiful in a haunting way. The riverbank was barely visible, just a hint of green that the eye hardly noticed, as it was drawn into the pale waters leading to a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people; and it felt right that way. There seemed to be no place for living things in this distant vision. Yet for some reason, she was fascinated, thinking about autumn coming after a long, rich summer. Mum spoke again. “It has a name.” There was something in her voice – too casual and detached – that showed her excitement. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his paintings. He just painted them and let others interpret them, if they could. Mum turned the painting over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written there. Jess read them aloud. “River Boy.” The words felt strangely significant to her, but she didn’t know why. There was another mystery. She looked at Mum. “There is no boy.” “Exactly. Strange, isn’t it – for him to be so specific. Still, he hasn’t finished it yet, so maybe he will add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it.” “Mum! You should have known better.” “I know, but I couldn’t help it. It’s such an unusual painting, especially with a name. I guess you can imagine his response.” Jess didn’t need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would have said. “He told you it’s not the artist’s job to explain a painting because each picture has its own life and language, just like a poem, and we either understand it or we don’t. And he said painting is hard enough work without having to explain it to every fool…” “Ignoramus, he said.” “...every ignoramus what it means. And if artists had to explain their paintings to everyone who asked, they’d never get any work done. And he said…” Mum interrupted her, laughing. “Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting, since you seem to inspire him.” “Inspire?” “Someone who motivates an artist.” She knew what the word meant. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but usually, it was just to say that the muse wasn’t helping him that day or that he needed to be nice to the muse because he had a tough part to work on. He never suggested the muse was about her. In fact, she always thought he meant some kind of goddess, not a real person. It was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as stubborn as Grandpa. “He doesn’t need me to inspire him,” she said. “He’s been painting all his life.”'

Text: 'When I woke up this morning, I didn’t plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I’m not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the edge of the bed while holding Dad’s Stanley knife, the blade might have accidentally gone into the carpet and made a big cut. I’m not saying that happened, just that it could have. I didn’t mean to damage the carpet. I didn’t wake up thinking, ‘Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.’ It just seemed like a good idea at the time, as things often do. Later, I wondered why I thought that, but by then it was too late. This happens to me quite often. I’m a bit unlucky in that way. 

What I was really doing was trying to find a way to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved from her house to a flat. It’s very cute! It’s small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers around the edge, and has tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in there: shepherdesses, milkmaids, and old-fashioned ladies selling balloons. I keep my collection of shells, fossils, and interesting stones in it. Gran knew I loved her corner cabinet, and I was so happy when she gave it to me! 

The problem is, it is a corner cabinet, which means it has to fit in a corner. I only have two corners in my bedroom because it’s the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is for Mum and Dad; the one at the back is my sister Angela’s; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom’s; and the tiny one that’s like a broom cupboard is mine. Mum says that when Angela goes to university, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. And when Tom goes to university, I can choose any room. But since Angela is only fifteen, I think I’ll be stuck in my broom cupboard for a long time. I don’t really mind; I like my little bedroom. It’s cozy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe is in the other. 

I tried to fit Gran’s cabinet into the space between the roof and the floor, but it was just a little too tall. Then I thought, if I can’t cut anything off Gran’s cabinet, how about cutting a hole in the carpet? It seemed like the obvious solution. What Dad calls lateral thinking. I thought he would be pleased with me. He always tells us to ‘think outside the box.’ And that was exactly what I was doing!'

The novel 'The Borrowers' tells the story of a family of tiny people who live secretly in the walls and floors of a house, borrowing things from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV adaptation of the novel, I knew it would be challenging to meet people's expectations. Fans of the book have strong opinions about how everything should look. I relied a lot on the original illustrations because I wanted to avoid criticism for getting it wrong. The author wanted the series to show the story from the Borrowers' point of view, not from the humans', which made filming more complicated. 

The most important aspect was getting the scale right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when we filmed them walking across a room or going on a borrowing mission, we had to position the camera ten times further away than usual. To capture the Borrowers' perspective, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters. They went through many pairs of jeans! We only raised the cameras for aerial shots. 

One major challenge was creating realistic shadows when combining images of the tiny Borrowers with the normal-sized surroundings. We developed a special technique for this. After the series aired, famous US director George Lucas called to ask how we achieved it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with oversized objects to make the actors appear small. It was wonderfully surreal. I remember asking them to carry giant scissors, and they really got into the spirit of it. The coins were particularly memorable; they were larger than dinner plates and hard to lift, often making the crew laugh so much that we had to pause filming.

In the story, there is a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, the actors had to be pushed down a tunnel with hoses, and they found it so frightening that they didn’t need to act. It was also important to me to get the costumes right, which has been a struggle for other directors. I had the costumes made from heavy canvas so they would stick out like dolls' clothes. This made it very difficult for the lead actress to move; she couldn’t sit down during breaks and had to be sewn into her dress every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal fabric would have looked too smooth. Unfortunately, it was very hot during filming, and I don’t think they appreciated my attention to detail with the costumes!

Most of the action away from the Borrowers' home was filmed with the actors in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was challenging for them to react to things that weren’t really there. I had to draw pictures of each scene to show everyone how it should look – I ended up drawing 2,000 of them. They weren’t perfect, but they were helpful. The budget didn’t allow for time in special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work quickly; I once filmed an entire scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But in the end, everything came together, and I believe the series successfully captured the magic of the books.

Text: 'Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, searching for journalists that aren’t there. I wonder how long it will take before the chaos starts. It always does. The fake smiles, the people who want to be my friends, and the ones asking for free tickets to my dad’s concerts. “Everything’s going to be fine,” I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me alone in this new school and situation. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to escape my old life on the road with tour tutors. While the rest of the band is renting here for recording, we’re staying for good. I insisted on coming to this school because I want to meet real kids for a change. How about a kid with a mom who works in an office or a dad who mows lawns? That would be so cool. 

I walk into the school’s main office. “Hi, I need my schedule, please,” I tell the school secretary. “Name?” She looks as friendly as an ice bucket. “Desert McGraw.” “Desirée?” she asks, leaning closer. “Desert,” I repeat. The secretary seems confused. “Oh,” she says and types “McGraw” on her keyboard. That’s one good thing. Few people recognize my last name because my dad uses his stage name. “What grade?” “Eleventh.” “One second, it’s printing,” the secretary says. Then she rips the sheet and hands it to me. English Literature, first period. Great, I can handle that. English has always been my favorite subject. I’ll be late, though. English is in Room 214, on the second floor. I studied the map last night so I wouldn’t look foolish searching for my classes. 

When I get to the door, I hear the teacher taking attendance. “Aurelio Gonzalez.” “Here.” She continues while I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles. Her eyes scan my very normal and, I might add, very clever outfit – jeans and a T-shirt. Ha! Nobody will suspect me now! “Nice shoes,” she whispers. I look down at my expensive platforms with tan embroidered flowers. Oh no, I knew I shouldn’t have worn these. “Thanks,” I say. The teacher pauses in the attendance. “Desert... McGraw?” she says hesitantly. “Here.” The teacher then smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and eventually gives us our course outlines. After we review them and she tells us about the books we need to read this year, she actually gives us time to socialize! All teachers should understand how important this is. 

“So why did you move here?” my new friend asks. I have a few options here. Do I say it’s because I wanted a normal life away from cameras, reporters, and the red carpet? Or the real reason, according to Dad? “We need a change, Desert,” he said, “and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed.” Personally, I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else would they choose South Beach Sounds, a recording studio just steps from the sand? “My dad had to relocate,” I tell her. Yes, lies work better. “What does he do?” she asks. Oh, whatever. Everyone will find out eventually. But at least I’ll have some time to pretend to be normal until they do. “He’s an artist,” I say, playing with the zipper on my backpack. “Cool. I’m Becca, by the way.” And she doesn’t seem to care. Excellent.'

Text: 

Today, the average American teenage girl is expected to be the Student Council president, have a part-time job, volunteer, and excel in all these areas. This is what it means to be a teenager in America now. Both boys and girls cannot just go to school and blend in; being average is no longer enough. Mediocrity is not acceptable, and not having high ambitions is seen as laziness. Teenager Kristen Loose explains, “People, often adults, forget how much pressure teenagers face today. We have a lot of homework, tests, extracurricular activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home, all while trying to maintain a social life.” 

Despite these pressures being common in teenage life today, negative stereotypes about teenagers still exist, often spread by the media. These stereotypes include being lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-centered. While some teenagers may fit these descriptions, many believe it is unfair to label the entire generation this way. Loose points out that many people think teenagers spend most of their time watching TV or using their phones. She acknowledges that she often has her cellphone nearby, but not for trivial reasons. It is a tool that helps teenagers manage their lives and responsibilities. 

Today, students are expected to have quick access to information and be reachable at all times, which can create the impression of cellphone addiction. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can do their homework anywhere. Instead of just listening to music on the way to school, they might be listening to language lessons. Schoolwork and other activities now require attention around the clock, adding to the stress of already busy teenagers. Many teenagers start their days around 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and often finish after midnight. Their schedules are filled with school, after-school activities, family duties, and homework, leaving them with less than the recommended nine hours of sleep each night. 

The US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20 percent of American teenagers get the recommended nine hours of sleep. Additionally, 28 percent of teens admitted to falling asleep in school about once a week due to lack of sleep. Teenager Lindamarie Olsen believes that after all her activities, she has about 18 hours of free time each week. With 168 hours in a week, 18 hours is not much. Olsen rarely spends her free time on social media or watching TV; instead, she dedicates much of her time to volunteering. She says, “The stereotype is that teenagers only care about themselves and their own interests.” However, Olsen enjoys volunteering and looks forward to making a positive impact in her school and community. 

In 20 years, the stereotype of teenagers may change, but they will continue to challenge these views and contribute positively to the world. Another generation of students will emerge, making their mark before they even finish school.

Text: 'The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in and around Bishop, a mountain town in the US, surrounded mostly by wilderness, east of the Sierra Nevada mountain range. In recent years, this isolated group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth's surface. This ongoing science project has a unique twist: it combines astronomy with adventure, which is likely why teenagers join. I joined them one weekend in late spring. They were about to release a high-altitude balloon to record shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or piece of metal from space enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a bright trail of light. As it got dark, the teenagers attached a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the bottom of the balloon. Inside were a camera, an instrument to measure altitude, and a thermometer to check temperature changes during the ascent. Two GPS trackers were placed on the outside of the lunch box to help the group find it later. A gas tank, donated by a supporter from a nearby state, was used to inflate the balloon, which slowly grew to the size of a small car. An older boy made a seven-hour round trip to get it. ‘I didn’t really mind,’ he said. For kids in this club, that’s just part of the experience. Finally, it was time for lift-off. ‘Five, four, three, two, one,’ they counted down, and the balloon began to rise. Some of them ran and tracked its path with powerful flashlights for as long as they could, lighting up the balloon in the dark sky. There was a quiet moment filled with wonder. Then the balloon disappeared into the night. After the launch, most students went home, but a few stayed to watch the shooting stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside, looking at a sky so clear that it was hard to believe they were only four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city with around 4 million people. I saw a boy climb into a sleeping bag and quickly fall asleep. ‘We're the only ones talking,’ said one girl quietly. ‘I know,’ whispered another. A meteor shot across the sky. As the balloon rose, the air pressure decreased, causing the balloon to expand until it was almost the size of a house. Then it popped with a loud bang. A parachute helped the equipment inside the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students would find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Retrieving it wasn’t easy, but that was part of the fun. There is little inhabited land around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in remote areas. ‘To me, recoveries are a big part of the program,’ said the group’s leader, noting they’ve lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. ‘Part of the journey has been getting to know this landscape in a way you normally wouldn’t.’ This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop, but to reach it, the recovery team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side of the mountain range.
