They also had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or in a tall tree. ‘It’s important to remember that these students are familiar with the Eastern Sierra,’ their leader said. ‘What may seem wild and dangerous to some is just a way of life for others.’ In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, on a flat rock, in the middle of a waterfall. The camera hadn’t recorded any shooting stars. While this was a bit disappointing, it also provided a chance to discuss the effects of atmospheric waves and how they might behave above mountain ridges. And it was one more adventure story to share with anyone who asked.'

Chloe Morgan admits that science, especially Palaeontology, did not interest her much until she was fifteen. It was more of an accident than a plan. “My younger brother was going through a dinosaur phase, which I had not experienced. I usually dismissed it. I helped him with a science project, and when I found an article about recent discoveries in Palaeontology, it amazed me. I realized this was something I wanted to pursue.”

I am curious about the support she received because Palaeontology was not a common career choice for young people back then. “I remember meeting my first professional palaeontologist,” she laughs. “This guy, Matt Cornelius, was already famous, even though he was quite young. I was very nervous, even though he was known for being friendly. I worried he would think I was just an annoying kid asking too many questions. It could have been awkward,” Chloe tells me. “But I felt more comfortable when he showed patience and listened to me.”

I ask her about how palaeontologists are shown in movies and TV shows. Chloe thinks for a moment. “I have to admit that films like Jurassic Park, which feature dinosaurs created with special effects, have increased public interest in these creatures, but not necessarily in Palaeontology itself. While I appreciate this interest, I find that the few palaeontologists shown in films are often portrayed inaccurately. We are either seen as eccentric geniuses or as socially awkward people who are the butt of jokes. Movies do not accurately represent our daily work life.”

I ask her to explain more. “My job is very varied. I spend a lot of time digging up dinosaur bones, but I also work long hours in laboratories, analyzing fossils and writing for scientific journals.” Although it is not something she does every day, she also communicates scientific findings to the public when she can. She takes this role seriously. “There are many misunderstandings about science, and while some colleagues avoid this challenge to focus on research, I believe it is important. I want to reach out to young people because it is essential to inform them about all aspects of science. Talking about dinosaurs can inspire children to learn about the natural world and explore other areas of science.”

The recent TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs gave Chloe a chance to influence how dinosaurs are shown on screen. She emphasizes that the creators of the program knew what they were doing, and she was there to offer advice if needed. “I had an easy time because there was little I needed to correct, like dinosaurs that were too big or the wrong shape; mostly, I checked that the dinosaurs shown lived during the same time period. We attracted audiences of all ages because we have learned so much about dinosaurs recently, and the ones in this program are very different from those in movies like Jurassic Park. They are the most realistic representations ever made.”

Why does Chloe think dinosaurs continue to fascinate us and remain a focus of research? “I believe they appeal to our natural curiosity. Our imaginations are drawn to the unknown and the idea of discovery. In a world that seems to be getting smaller, prehistoric creatures remind us that there is still much to explore. Palaeontology is a wonderful way to travel through time.”

Text: "I will say this once: when you are traveling by car with your family, even if you are six years old, you know that you are not ‘there yet,’ even when you keep asking, ‘Are we there yet?’ The truth is, once you arrive, it’s not ‘there’ anymore; it’s ‘here.’ So if you think you might be ‘there’ already, you should be asking, ‘Are we here yet?’ I’m sure no one wishes they were ‘there yet’ more than the parents who hear that question over and over on long car trips. 

Think about it. Wouldn’t you rather relax in the back seat, with no responsibilities? You could watch DVDs you’ve never seen, listen to music, or do puzzles you’ve had for a long time, while beautiful views pass by outside the window. In the front seat, there’s a parent with a map, giving out juice boxes and cookies, adjusting the radio, and making sure everything runs smoothly. 

‘Are we there yet?’ I hope not. That is, until someone in the car does something annoying—usually my younger brother, Tim. For example, he might put his foot on my side of the seat. I can’t let that happen, so I put my foot on his side. Then he puts his other foot on mine, and soon he’s all over my space, and a fight starts. The driver and the other parent have to reach back and separate us while the car swerves. They tell Tim to stay in his own seat and keep his hands to himself. This calms things down for a bit, and the beautiful scenery continues to pass by.

After a while, I try to read, but then I feel a draft on my arm. The car isn’t going fast, and the window isn’t open. Where is it coming from? My brother is next to me, quietly blowing his breath in my direction. He’s not touching me, so he thinks he’s being clever. Just breathing? What’s wrong with that? The anger builds again. Tim gets yelled at, and the car swerves more. Eventually, things calm down again.

Over the years, Dad has come up with ways to handle us in the back seat. For example, when we ask, ‘Are we there yet?’ he often replies, ‘Yes. We’re here. Get out of the car.’ ‘But Dad, we’re still on the highway, going 70 miles an hour.’ ‘Oh, well, then maybe we’re not there yet.’ That keeps us quiet for a while. 

You can tell when you finally arrive because the adults jump out of the car and go as far away as possible from the kids who have bothered them for hours. So remember: if Mom and Dad are still close enough to answer your question, then the answer is: no. You’re not there yet."

Text: 'John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee and cake while playing board games. The owners hope that customers will love the experience and want to come back. Zuzi explains their motivation for starting this business: “There is so much technology today. Everyone is busy with their mobile phones and gadgets. We wanted to bring people together in a way that doesn’t involve staring at screens. It’s natural for people to connect and communicate with each other.” The games played in their café are called ‘Eurogames’. These games often have gentle themes, like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan (now called Catan), created by German designer Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements on an island and trade resources, keeping everyone engaged until the end, so no one feels left out. This idea was improved in ‘co-operative’ games, where all players either win or lose together, encouraging more social interaction. Pandemic, a Eurogame where players work together to solve global problems, was created by North American designer Matt Leacock, who is very successful in the tabletop gaming world. He was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings, based on the book. “When I played that with friends, we felt scared and excited,” Leacock remembers. “In the end, everyone felt good, whether they won or lost. I wanted to create something like that.” Leacock’s love for board games started when he was a child. “Games were my favorite birthday gift,” he says, “but I would get very excited, open the box, and then feel disappointed when we played.” With help from his game-loving uncle, young Leacock would change the games they played to try to make them better. Pandemic became a huge success, and its follow-up version advanced game design even further. Leacock explains, “It has a lot of storytelling. It’s like an electronic game where you develop characters, get new rules, and the world changes. It tells a story as you play.” Surprisingly, the growth of the video game industry has helped the success of modern board games. The presence of game consoles and mobile gaming has made playing games more common. “Video games and board games have learned a lot from each other,” says Ben Hogg from a leading games company. “Everyone plays games on their smartphones now. More people are open to playing games than ever before.” For a while, video gaming allowed some physical social interaction, like at arcades or multiplayer games played together in the same room. However, as multiplayer video games moved online, players became physically distant from each other. Some people who enjoyed video games began to seek ways to play games with others who were physically present. As seen in John and Zuzi's busy café, tabletop gaming has become more than just entertainment. In our increasingly online world, games are now something to be shared in person, and this trend is likely to continue.'

Text: Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest hits in the UK in recent years. His story shows why endurance and persistence are important in the music business, even if your career starts with many setbacks. He mentions that his mother was an amazing singer who encouraged him to start playing the guitar. The only radio station he listened to at home was a local one aimed at middle-aged people, which influenced his musical tastes as he grew up. He was 12 years old when he first heard a contemporary song. Around the same time, he had to choose between tennis, which he played at a national level, and music. He spent his lunchtimes in the school music room learning songs on the piano. He recalls, “With tennis, I was at a high level, but it wasn’t what I wanted to do for my whole life. It was just too much hard work.” At 17, he left school to pursue a career as a performer. He formed a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but not as passionate about performing. Jamie remembers telling his parents, “This is what I want to do. I’ve been writing lyrics in economics class and playing the piano every day while others were outside.” His father gave him 18 months to succeed; if he didn’t, he would need to find a job. After several near misses with record labels, he was signed to a music publisher at 19 based on one song. However, record labels wanted him to be a solo artist, so he had to part ways with his friend. Ultimately, he found success behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he asked to leave and joined another label to release a new album. However, fame and fortune did not come easily. He reflects, “In my artist career, I often felt like I was in the wrong place at the wrong time. But as a writer, I’ve been in the right place at the right time.” Writing for other artists is where he truly found his success. He believes he is one of the main writers in the UK that labels turn to for new artists. He sometimes has to explain to these artists that aiming for chart success is not something to be ashamed of. He asks, “Why don’t you want to? Don’t you want 10 million people streaming your music next month?” He emphasizes that they should aim to create something amazing that is also likely to sell well. It is refreshing to hear someone in pop music speak openly about wanting to write hit songs. Jamie is not arrogant; he simply understands that he wants to write number one hits and has the talent to do so. Instead of worrying about how he sounds to others, he focuses on his goals. He states, “When I go into the studio with someone, we need to aim for global success and write the best music of the next year. It’s not just about what’s cool; we want to create classic modern pop songs.”

Text: 'Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity: a big star online, but probably unknown to people who don’t watch online videos of stunts on bikes. He is a ‘street trials cyclist’ – he jumps from one difficult place, like a roof or a wall, to land safely in another unusual spot. These stunts are filmed and shared online. On the day I interview him, we meet in a BMX park on a Saturday morning. The local kids all know who he is, and we stop a few times as older people come to greet him, calling him ‘an absolute legend’. After seeing some of his skills, I have to agree. Even though I came with doubts, I am impressed by his courage, creativity, and willingness to take risks. Before each stunt, he explains what he plans to do, and I sometimes can’t believe he will succeed. However, when I compliment him afterwards, he seems indifferent and a bit down. Despite his online fame, Tony admits he is not comfortable with being a celebrity. ‘I find the social side difficult. I see the value of connecting with fans, but I prefer to actually do things rather than just talk about them.’ This is ironic because his fame comes from social media and the lightweight cameras that create much of that content. ‘This technology allows people like me to earn a living,’ he says. ‘Sometimes I feel like everyone is filming themselves or looking at a screen, and I don’t fully agree with that.’ However, he is not complaining. Through his videos, he makes a good living from what would have been just a hobby in the past. After many years of interviewing top athletes, I have learned that two important factors turn a passionate child into a top competitor: energy and the ability to handle disappointment. These qualities may be more important than talent and help build the mental strength needed to keep going despite failure. The riskier the sport, the more mental strength is needed. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times on what he considered easy but new challenges. He just brushed himself off and kept trying until he succeeded. Not everyone sees Tony as a hero. Some people think he is reckless and takes unnecessary risks. He says, ‘Those who criticize me may be genuinely worried, but they don’t understand. They probably have never ridden a trials bike and know little about the sport. They don’t realize that I get advice from experts to minimize risks.’ In fact, Tony is careful about the risks he takes. ‘People are different. Some never feel scared, and they probably shouldn’t do these sports; it’s important to be aware of dangers. The rest of us can be divided into those who can overcome fear and those who cannot. I belong to the group that feels fear but finds a way to move past it. I’m not addicted to risk; I spend hours planning and preparing. Sometimes I ride around for a while to get in the right mindset before trying a new stunt. I know I must not lose my nerve just before I jump. If I commit fully, then I’m fine.’

Text: 'Television presenter Helen Skelton has taken on many dangerous challenges for charity, such as running a marathon in the desert and traveling down the Amazon river in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire, which is a long thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net; she only had a belt around her waist attached to another wire above. To help her balance and avoid falling, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. Helen trained with an expert high-wire walker. Even though she had some circus skills, she found that high-wire walking was very different. ‘The training was a shock,’ said Helen. ‘I didn’t know how strong I needed to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill, followed by an hour of exercises, and then another hour practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so that if I slipped, I could keep going. Every time I fell on the wire, it hurt a lot. But it was important to stay positive: if I was nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!’ On the day of the challenge, it was windy, and Helen calmed herself by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. ‘That was the scariest thing I’ve done,’ she said afterwards. ‘I’m glad it’s over!’ However, this experience has not stopped Helen from planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by ski, kite, and bike.'

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, an old-style bicycle with one large wheel and one small wheel. He had previously written a book about his travels in Canada using a 50-year-old car. Jeff loved motorsport and worked building racing car engines. To save money, he rode an old bicycle to work and also used it for a holiday in Amsterdam. He said, “That trip opened my eyes. I decided to see the world by bike.” Jeff wanted a unique touring bike and decided to build one himself. He thought a penny farthing would be the most interesting choice, so he visited a museum to learn how they were made. After two attempts in 2001 and 2003, which ended because of a knee injury, he finally began his journey in 2006. He traveled for three years, visiting 23 countries across four continents. The highlight of his trip was reaching Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. He met cyclists who could ride up mountains, but he never regretted his choice of the penny farthing. The further he traveled from home, the more people were amazed by it. His worst experience was having to drink dirty water from a stream, which made him very sick. He spent ten days in a hostel without medicine and had no money for a hospital or to return home. Despite these challenges, Jeff now says, “If I could afford it, I would start traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.”

Text: "I work at a university in the US with my team to learn more about water birds, especially the American black duck. We have just started using a new tool called a ‘night-vision scope’, which helps us see the ducks in the dark. We are concerned about black ducks because their numbers have decreased a lot, and we are unsure if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We know a lot about what they do during the day, but we don’t have information about their nighttime activities because we didn’t have the right equipment. This new scope will give us clear images, even on nights without a moon, so we can learn more and make better decisions about protecting their habitat. It is hard work. There are four of us, and we each work six hours a day. We have studied ducks in different places, and I have had to take a boat to some locations and write down every duck I see. The weather has been challenging – some nights are warm, but often it is rainy. It is so quiet that I have needed a lot of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one workday because the snow was too deep for our special vehicles. Still, I enjoy the challenge, especially compared to the summer when we will spend hours in a laboratory analyzing our results. It will be difficult to be indoors, but it is necessary. I wouldn’t change this experience for anything!"

Text: "When I tell people about my job, they often find it hard to believe it exists. But I’m serious! I spend my workdays tasting chocolate! Tasting is a crucial part of ensuring that customers receive perfect, high-quality chocolate from my company. Each week, I get samples, which are small amounts of chocolate from our factory, and I need to check them for taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we usually use, like nuts and fruit, to choose the best ones for the chocolate. Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I can test and taste the products I create, and I keep my colleagues happy by sharing samples! My kitchen is filled with machines and ingredients to experiment with. It’s great to have a private space to go to during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I work in our food lab, and other times I travel abroad to buy raw materials, which can be challenging since I have a young family. However, I enjoy the variety and lack of routine in my job, although I think the chocolate itself is the best part! People often ask me if I ever get bored of chocolate. I’ve worked with it for a long time, and I’ve never felt tired of eating it. In fact, I often go home and eat more in the evening!"

Text: 'Have you ever thought about what it’s like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson works at Circus Experience, a center that teaches young people circus skills. She says her course is popular because it includes many skills, such as juggling, throwing and catching objects like balls or even fire, and trapeze, which involves flying through the air in front of an amazed audience. 

In the year-long course, students gradually take more risks in each class, and parents can come to some classes to see their progress. Sophia explains, “For a circus career, performers need to avoid doing the same thing repeatedly – it’s important to keep performances exciting and full of action. If you want to be successful in the circus, you must keep practicing. Another great aspect is the friendships with other performers and the chance to learn from them. Staying fit is also very important – circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is essential, but the best performers are those who desire success, have creativity, and never stop improving their skills. 

People often think you are likely to get injured or that you might only work for a short time each year. However, the real challenge is planning for the future because you can only travel while you’re young, and then you need to think about other options.” The course also includes business planning. Many former students have started businesses around the world and are happy to share their experiences. Sophia warns, though, that it’s not a profession for making a lot of money! “The work usually means not having a regular salary. It’s also competitive – but a lot of fun!”'

Text: 'You may not know her name or face, but you have probably heard her many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer, someone who supports the main singer by singing in the background. Many people think that backing singers are not good enough to be lead singers, but that is not true – they often have to be even better. People like Mariam are the real stars of the music industry! 

“What I love about my job is that when I enter the recording studio, I never know what I will be asked to sing,” she says. “It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. It might even be a funny little song for a radio station or an advertisement. I am often surprised by what producers ask for. Once, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never complain; I just do my job!”

“Excellent musical skills are very important for my work, as well as the ability to learn quickly. There is often no written music to follow. I will never forget my first experience recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different part, along with an orchestra. I was scared because I knew that if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, which nobody likes. Recording sessions are already long enough.”

“One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers do not always know which musical range is best for a female voice. By listening to me sing their song, they can figure out how to improve it.”

Text: 'Starting with only basic knowledge of fashion, Julie Deane has built a successful business selling ‘satchels’ - traditional bags used by schoolchildren. These satchels are now sold in famous shops and are popular among many celebrities. Before deciding on satchels, Julie made a list of different business ideas, such as cake decorating and party planning, carefully considering her options instead of just going with her first thought. Once she made her choice, she found that not everyone supported her. Julie recalls, ‘Many said there was no demand for them – but I was convinced.’ She involved her family from the beginning, working with her mother, who had never had a career but had a natural talent for business. The design of the satchels was inspired by children’s storybooks. Although Julie was not very familiar with fashion blogs, they played a key role in her success. Initially, she sold about one satchel a week. To generate interest, Julie sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would write about them in their blogs. They did, and interest in her products continued to grow, along with the speed at which her company produced the satchels. Julie now enjoys waiting to see which celebrity is seen with a satchel! While other companies spend money on online advertising, she uses the internet community for ideas on new styles, keeping her products fresh and exciting. There was a difficult time when another company copied Julie’s design to sell similar bags. As a result, she now ensures she has confidence in her production team, just as she does in her own staff. Visitors often comment on the positive atmosphere in her offices – people enjoy working there. There is now a new factory, and while the buildings are important, it is the team that makes it a special place.'

Text: 'When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents allowed her and her brother Jamie to choose how they spent their free time. Vicky decided to try many different sports. She was a good swimmer, and her coach at the swimming club believed she could become a champion. However, the club was far from her home, making it hard for her to balance training with her schoolwork. As teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and began competing. Vicky thought this looked exciting and decided to try cycling too. She says it was the best decision she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The track was close to her school, so it was easy for her to attend training sessions after school. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won several competitions. When she was 28, she retired from competitive cycling. Vicky explained, ‘For years, I loved winning competitions, but I started to feel tired of it all – when the excitement fades, it loses its meaning. Fortunately, I found a new career.’ Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. ‘We work with young people who have never enjoyed sports,’ she says. ‘The first thing we do is teach them to ride a bike. We want them to learn to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does a great job of bringing young people together so they feel part of a larger community.’ The charity uses celebrities to promote their work. Vicky says, ‘I know some people doubt whether celebrity support is always good for a charity. They argue that celebrities may be doing it for their own benefit, which can distract from the charity's real work. But if famous singers and actors can help, I believe they should.’

Text: 'Singer-songwriter Ana Ronson grew up in Ireland. Even though her parents were not musicians, there was always music in their home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother how to play. The first time Ana sang in front of an audience was at school. She was so nervous that her teacher had to help her off the stage. This teacher suggested that joining the school theatre club might help her feel more confident. After being in the club for a while, she happily sang with 50 other students at a concert at the end of the term. A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song, Falling Stars, in just three days and enjoyed it so much that she signed up for a songwriting course with a professional songwriter. Although she was the youngest student, she already knew more about music than many of the others. However, Ana felt that the teacher did not listen to her, and she wrote a song called Something to Say about how frustrated this made her feel. She shared this song online, and it became very popular. She was thrilled when people commented that they loved it and found new meanings in the lyrics each time they listened. Joss Alton, the owner of a recording company called Isotope Music, traveled from the other side of Ireland to invite her to join Isotope. At first, she was unsure because she did not know much about the company and did not want anyone telling her what to sing. However, Joss convinced her that this would not happen, and soon after, she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. They sold all the tickets quickly, and it was a wonderful evening. Ana says she is less interested in writing songs about happy times; when life is difficult, she feels she has more to express. One of her favorite songs is Decision, which is about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how unhappy it made him. While she hopes her fans will enjoy her songs, her goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.'

Text: 'Last year, I went on an incredible trip – traveling by boat on a guided group tour along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He is a journalist, like me, and he wanted to write articles about the trip. He loves boats, although that’s not an interest we share. I had dreamed of visiting the area since I saw it on TV as a child, especially because I knew it was where our great-grandparents had lived before moving to Europe. So, I kept asking Harry if I could join him – until he finally agreed! A few days before we left, there were storms in the area we were going to. But luckily, the weather forecast for our trip was for calm seas. Although there was a lot to arrange, I was busy at work and didn’t have much time to think about what needed to be done. But Harry promised he’d taken care of everything, so I stopped worrying. After arriving in Canada, we joined the group, packed our limited supplies into small boats, and set off. The guide mentioned that very few people now lived along that coast, and sure enough, the only other living creatures we saw that first morning were dolphins and birds. We knew there were islands in the distance, but the early-morning fog made it hard to see far, so I just focused on the beautiful patterns our boat made in the water. We often stopped for hours to explore the rock pools on the beaches. They were full of amazing colorful fish, many of which I didn’t recognize. It was great to stop worrying about how quickly or slowly the day was passing. We never forgot lunch or dinner, though, which we all made together over campfires. When we finally fell asleep on the boats each evening, even though the beds were hard, it really felt like a stress-free life! When it was time to leave, I felt sad. How could I return to normal life? But I knew if I stayed, I’d miss my family and friends. I was also looking forward to telling everyone at home about our adventures!'

Text: "My dad was a professional basketball player in Germany, just like his father before him. When I was a kid, I watched many of his games. You might think that seeing so many matches would make me love basketball, but it actually did the opposite. I enjoyed telling my friends how good my dad was, especially when he won, but I often took a book to read instead of watching the games.

When I started secondary school, I was still two years away from being a teenager, but I was already two meters tall. Because of my height, my sports teacher asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I liked the training, but I thought I needed to improve my skills before playing in a real match. However, the teacher believed in me more than I believed in myself. After some time, I agreed, and a few weeks later, I played against another school’s team. My parents watching made me more nervous, but it turned out fine!

For the next four years, I practiced every day and did very well, even joining an adult team before moving to a special sports academy in the USA when I was fifteen. The coach there trains Olympic basketball players, and it was amazing to work with him. However, I didn’t enjoy living far from my parents at first. At home, I hadn’t spent much time with friends because of all the training, so that part wasn’t a big change for me. Eventually, I got used to my new life, and my English improved quickly too!

I became a professional player at eighteen, three years after arriving in the USA. I had been taller than most players in the professional league since I was fifteen, but I needed to gain weight to match my height. My coach knew a team that would take me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted it."

Text: "Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism at college and needed a part-time job because my course was quite expensive. After thinking about different options, I decided to train as a weekend tour guide in my home city, Chicago, USA. This meant showing visitors around the city, and I was surprised by how much I enjoyed giving those tours. I got to see the city I had lived in my whole life from the perspective of tourists, and it felt like a new experience each time! After I finished my studies, I chose to become a full-time tour guide. I thought it would be easy, but when I looked into it, I learned that to get a license as a full-time tour guide, I needed to know much more than I had learned so far. All Chicago guides must answer many questions about the city, including local architecture, history, and public transport rules. After several challenging but interesting months, I earned my tour guide qualification and registered as an independent tour guide. 

Being a tour guide is not just about knowing historical facts or keeping track of your group in crowds. There are many other important skills. You need to be entertaining and tell interesting stories, and most importantly, you must be able to adapt to changing situations. For example, if a place you thought was open is actually closed when you arrive, or if the route changes. Tourists do not want to hear about problems or feel like they are missing out; they just want to enjoy a well-organized tour. I have to ensure that visitors are happy with my tours, or they might leave a negative review online. Like most tour guides, I understand that these reviews are very important because good reviews attract more customers. That’s why it is essential to make tours enjoyable and stress-free. For me, the enthusiasm and energy I put into my job mean that my reviews are usually very good, and my tours are often recommended to other visitors coming to Chicago."

Text: 'My name is Ella, and I am 22 years old. Last year, I went to Thailand for two weeks with my sister, Josie. Even though she is five years younger than me, we have a good relationship. We went to volunteer at an elephant sanctuary, which is a place where people care for sick and rescued elephants. At first, I was unsure if we would connect with the other volunteers because they were all older than us. We were also nervous since it was our first time doing something like this. However, we ended up having a great experience. 

One of our main tasks at the sanctuary was to collect food for the elephants. Elephants eat a lot of grass and banana plants, so this took most of our day. Josie found it very hard work, but seeing the elephants enjoy their meals made it worthwhile for me. We also helped wash the elephants in the river using large brushes and soap. I found this very enjoyable, even though I got wetter than the elephants! 

The part of the day I looked forward to the most was the evening. By moonlight, we led the elephants into the forest where they spent the night. All the volunteers stayed in the same house. Josie and I shared a bedroom, which was a bit cramped, but we chose to do this because Josie didn’t want to be alone. It was hot and humid, especially at night, but we expected that. The meals were delicious and did not include meat, which we both do not like. After dinner, all the volunteers and staff spent the evenings talking and playing games. 

Now that we are back in the UK, Josie does not often talk about Thailand. But if someone asks her if she enjoyed her time at the sanctuary, she says she loved it. However, I think she might be a little upset with herself for not fully enjoying her time there because she missed her friends too much. But when she reflects on the experience, she realizes how lucky she was to go. Maybe she will return one day – I definitely will!'

Text: "My name is Gina D’Costa, and I own a flower shop in the UK. We sell flowers not only to people buying them for friends or their homes, but also to many different customers. Hotels and offices often have flowers in their reception areas, and sometimes we provide flowers for businesses' advertising photos. Once, I even decorated a castle with flowers for a wedding. It was a lot of work, but I was very proud of what we accomplished. 

My day starts at 4 a.m. when I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. Most people are still asleep at that time, and my friends think I’m a bit crazy, but I love what I do. It can be colder and darker than I would like, but I don’t let that bother me. The flower market is amazing, with flowers from all over the world. The sights and smells make it hard to choose. If I were picking flowers for myself, I would probably choose only pink ones because it’s my favorite color. However, I have to remember that my preferences may not match what my customers want. 

Sometimes, it’s difficult to find the flowers that customers want because not all flowers are available all year round. I don’t enjoy negotiating prices with the flower sellers, but it’s part of the job. Flowers can be expensive, so I try to get the best price possible. 

Back at the shop, we look at customer orders and prepare vases with the flowers I bought. Then, we create flower arrangements and calculate the costs of the orders. Customers are often surprised by the prices, and I sometimes have to ask them to reconsider their choices. Some people might think this is too much trouble, but I enjoy figuring out how to create the best flower arrangements for the budget someone has. That’s what you need to do when you’re selling things – I wouldn’t want any other job!"

Text: "My city has a modern cinema that shows all the latest films, including many for kids on weekends. It’s close to my home, but a year ago, I realized something was missing – the chance to discuss a film in detail with others after watching it. So, with two friends, I started a film club! We decided not to rent a cinema for our screenings. Instead, we choose a different location in the city each month. For example, we used an old factory to show a film set in Antarctica. It was very cold, which created the perfect atmosphere for the film, and it was fantastic! Some places we use are even free, as the owners sell snacks during the film, allowing us to keep our prices low. We are happy to cover our costs – we are not trying to make a profit. Each time we show a film, it gets easier for us, especially now that we have our own reliable equipment. We can also track ticket sales online, so we don’t worry about empty seats anymore! There is always a lot to do, but when people of all ages tell us at the end how much they enjoyed the experience, it feels great. Our website has been very helpful, and we are now connected with other film clubs across the country. We have visited them to see how they operate, but it’s always nice to return to our own club! We have also started a blog because we know that most people look online for film information instead of reading local reviews. We have tried putting up a few posters in cafés, but nothing is as effective as word of mouth – people telling their friends about us. The audience loves the special activities we organize with each film – last month, we had a movie quiz that everyone enjoyed."

Text: "Taking photographs was always my favorite activity as a child. When I turned 15, I wanted to take my hobby further, so I decided to start a special project: I would take one photograph every day for a whole year. Many young photographers had done this before, but I thought it was a great idea, so I began. After a few weeks, I decided to share my photos on a website for young photographers. I wanted to create a photo diary and show others my work. I was surprised to find that many people liked my perspective and style. I enjoyed photographing a variety of subjects. Then someone suggested that if my photos had a common theme, my project would be even better, and I agreed. I started focusing more on nature, especially birds and the sky. Most of my photos were in black and white, which was different from what many other young photographers were doing, as they were taking color photos. This made me doubt my project at times, and I almost gave up. However, I learned to trust my feelings and became more confident in my style and choices. One day, I showed my project to my art teacher. She told me about a national photography competition for my age group, so I entered some of my photos just for fun. I will never forget the moment the judges announced that I had won first prize; I was so happy because my project meant a lot to me. It was the first time I realized that my photography might be good, and that I could work as a professional photographer. Now, I have my own photography studio, and I have never regretted my career choice."

Text: 'I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) last year because I wanted to try new activities like camping, sailing, and public speaking. In the NYC, you can take part in various activities that help you grow and learn. There are different levels, from beginner to advanced, led by adult volunteers called ‘leaders’. When you finish each level, you receive a certificate. 

When I first joined, my leader suggested that I help organize activities at a local children’s club for two hours a week. I was unsure about this because I had joined that same club when I was eight and found it hard to make friends. I was shy, and the other children already had their own groups, so I stopped going after a few weeks. However, I decided to accept the challenge because I wanted my first NYC certificate. 

Soon, I found myself wanting to spend all my free time at the children’s club. It became much more important to me than just getting the certificate. After I completed the challenge, the NYC leader allowed me to continue volunteering at the club because I had formed good relationships with the children. Now, I spend about four hours a week there, and I always look forward to it. 

Because of what I learned at the children’s club, I have decided that after I finish school in three years, I want to go to college to become a qualified youth worker, someone who helps children. I had never thought about my future job or youth work before starting at the club. This has been my favorite part of the NYC so far, and I have improved my communication skills while helping others. I now have several NYC certificates, including one for camping!'

Text: 'I was born in Denver, USA, and I started snowboarding when I was eight years old. My dad took me to a resort in the mountains, about two hours from Denver. The hill looked very steep, so my dad had to convince me to try snowboarding. I was too young to ask him if I could start, but he loved the sport and wanted me to enjoy it too. He made it look easy, and eventually, I did well. After that first experience, I quickly grew to love snowboarding and improved my skills. I began competing when I was ten. Some people enter many competitions and get bored, but my passion for competing and winning has only grown stronger as I’ve aged, which motivates me to work harder. I like not having a strict plan, and sometimes this works out well, like when I became the first female to score a perfect 100 at a local competition. I wasn’t sure I would even try the jumps that earned me that score until I actually started. That achievement boosted my confidence in my abilities. In the summer, I focus on training and my studies when there’s no snow. Even though I train every day, it’s nice not to follow a strict diet like I do in winter. I also get to spend a lot of time with my friends, which helps me cope with not being able to do what I love. I need to think about my future. Snowboarding is a big part of my life now, but I also believe it’s important to have another option in case I don’t become a professional snowboarder or if I get injured. I’m considering whether becoming a doctor is possible if my active lifestyle allows time for college. I can’t imagine getting tired of snowboarding, but I know I can’t do it forever.'

Text: 'When I was fifteen, I wanted everything my friends had, and I never thought about the future. For example, I didn’t know what I wanted to do after school. One day, my best friend got a new phone for her birthday, and I thought I should have one too. My parents said I could only have it if I paid for it myself, so I decided to work part-time and save money. I am grateful to my parents for making me do that – it taught me an important lesson. I worked every Saturday in a café, but I didn’t enjoy it much, so my parents suggested I start my own small business. I had seen my mum making necklaces, so I asked if I could try that. I never thought I would find it so easy, as it looked complicated when I watched Mum. My friends thought it sounded boring, but I was excited about it. Mum showed me that I could create something nice at home with simple tools and materials. I sold my first pieces of jewellery to my friends and family as soon as I finished making them. They said they loved them, but I thought they were just being nice. Even though I was happy they bought them, I still needed to be sure they looked good enough for other people. The only way to find out was to rent a market stall with my mum. There are many tourists where I live, and they bought a lot of my items to take home. Soon, we started getting calls from all over the country from people wanting to buy more. They thought we were a big company with many workers, but we were just two people at a market stall! That was when I realized it could work, and it was time to take the next step – creating a website. Since then, I’ve made thousands of pounds from my business, mostly online, but we still have our stall too. It has been a lot of fun so far.'

Text: 'When Janine Stuart was just 13 years old, she wrote a novel called Being Amelia, which became a bestseller. Being Amelia is partly inspired by Janine’s own life. In an interview about her book, Janine said, “Because of my father’s job, my family moved around the country a lot, so I’ve learned to make new friends easily. I know what it’s like to be the only new student in a class, and that helped me write about how the main character, Amelia, adjusts to a new school. Some of the funniest parts of the book are about Amelia’s home life, especially her relationship with her older brother. Since I’m my parents’ only child, I had to use my imagination to describe that.” 

Janine started her novel one summer when she was bored at home. Her mother had always wanted to be a published author, and her teachers encouraged her to write, so it felt natural for Janine to spend her time this way. The year before, she had entered a short story competition on a young writers’ website and won first prize. That’s why, when Janine finished Being Amelia and sent it to a publishing company, they were eager to read it. They loved it, and a year later, Janine’s novel was available in bookstores. 

One review of Being Amelia notes that, despite the book having pictures of happy teenagers on the cover, the characters face real challenges, which makes them believable. The reviewer mentions that even though Janine is still very young and Being Amelia isn’t a long novel, she has shown that she is a better writer than many other bestselling authors. Janine is still adjusting to being a famous writer: “At first, I would hide when people recognized me in the street, but now it’s fine. I want to give advice to other young writers, but they need to find what works for them. For me, I know that if I spend time with my friends, I’ll soon have something interesting to write about!”'

Text: "My name is Tom, and I am fifteen years old. Three years ago, my family and I moved to a castle on a small island. This happened because my father was invited to manage the castle. He works for an organization that takes care of historical buildings and keeps them open to visitors. He was happy about this opportunity, but it took some time for the rest of us to agree that he should accept the job. We were worried about what life on the island would be like. We knew the castle might not be as comfortable as our warm home across the water, and there was no school nearby. However, once we moved, we quickly adapted to island life. The castle is not very beautiful, but our apartment in it is comfortable. In summer, the island is lively with many visitors, and there are often beach parties. In winter, we mostly see the other families who live on the island, but there are not many teenagers among them, which I had hoped for. The adults help each other and work together on repairs around the island, which can be hard work. 

The biggest change for me was taking a boat every day to my old school. I looked forward to going on stormy days when there are big waves, but the ferries do not run then! I also learned that if I miss the bus to the harbor after school, I will miss the last ferry home, which is stressful. So, when my friends come to visit, I always tell them to hurry! But we often enjoy amazing views, especially when the sun sets over the sea. Some days, it is so foggy that you cannot see anything, but within hours, it can be bright and sunny again. This still surprises me, even after living here for a while. Of course, we do experience terrible storms, and I sometimes wonder if the castle is strong enough to withstand them. But then I remind myself that it has been here for centuries and is still standing!"

Text: 'I live in a house in the beautiful countryside of Scotland. I have always loved nature and wild animals, and six years ago, I started a new hobby – birdwatching! I went to the mountains in northern Scotland with my family, where we saw many birds in their natural habitat. I spent hours watching them with my parents, who taught me how to identify different species and find the best places to see them. It was amazing, and after returning home, I joined a local birdwatchers’ club for young people. My goal is to see 200 different bird species, and I am close to achieving that. During family holidays abroad, I have had the chance to see birds from other countries as well. We always look for places with group birdwatching activities so I can add new birds to my list! I have been to Egypt, and last summer we went to South America, where I thought I would see my 200th species. I was not too disappointed when it didn’t happen, as I have learned that patience is important in this hobby. I posted a video online about this challenge, and many teenagers enjoyed it and commented that it looked like a fascinating hobby. When my teachers saw it, they asked me to give a presentation about birdwatching at school. I didn’t feel nervous until just before they introduced me and I walked onto the stage. I knew I would remember what to say and had some notes to help me, but the whole school and all my friends were watching! I only relaxed when it was over, and the teachers said I had prepared well and they really enjoyed it. I might even do another presentation next year! I am lucky to live in the countryside. I understand why many teenagers in cities might not think about becoming birdwatchers, but there are actually many birds to see, especially in areas with lots of green spaces. I also believe that birdwatching clubs should try to attract more young people to this hobby. Everyone needs to connect with nature, no matter their age, and it doesn’t have to cost much.'

Text: "I began playing football when I was 7 years old. I would hurry home from school to play with other kids. I loved it, and after some time, I became a decent player. My family knew I often got excited about new hobbies and then lost interest, so they probably thought I would do the same with football. But that never happened. In fact, I started dreaming of playing football professionally when I grew up. The chance came sooner than I expected. I played in local tournaments, and one referee saw that I was a talented player, so he asked the manager of a professional women’s club to watch me. After that, she invited me to join her club. I was surprised at first – I didn’t know young girls could join women’s clubs. But the manager was impressed, and I began regular training with a big club when I was just 13. After that, I improved a lot. Still, some people were unsure if I would ever be a star player, which made me a little sad. But the coach encouraged me to be myself and to believe in myself – he even let me play in one of the club’s championship matches earlier than I expected! I’ve never run so hard in my life – I didn’t want the other players to blame me if we lost. Then, by chance, I scored the winning goal. Even with the large crowd, I could hear my coach cheering for me, and after the match, the team carried me around the pitch. It was amazing! Since then, I’ve scored many more winning goals! Next month, my coach and I are organizing a football tournament in my area. The goal is to get teenagers interested in football and to give them a chance to meet other players in my club. It will show them the professional environment and encourage them to believe they could play for a top team if they are willing to work hard. My advice to them will be the same as my coach gave me – you will have good times, but be ready for some tough times too. I’ve had very few tough times, though – so I’ve been lucky!"

Text: 

In recent years, there has been an interesting trend in further and higher education in the UK and around the world. This trend encourages new students to get involved in research as early as possible in their studies. It acknowledges that research is not just for famous scholars at old universities or scientists making new discoveries, but is also a natural way to build knowledge and skills. Research skills are valuable not only for your studies but also for your future job, as they help you think critically about the world and your work.

As a student, you contribute to knowledge. You do not just learn and repeat information; you create it. Creating knowledge involves asking questions instead of accepting things as they are. You might wonder: Why? How? When? What does this mean? What if things were different? How does it work in this situation? What should we think about the facts, views, or beliefs we encounter? Why is this important? These questions are at the heart of what we call research.

Research can be seen as a range of activities. On one end, there is complex, groundbreaking research done by highly trained experts, which leads to significant changes and new knowledge. However, research can also start from simple inquiries that involve careful work, thoughtful questions about issues, and practical suggestions. Most students have always been researchers in some way. You have likely done research for school projects or answered questions at work since you began studying. You have asked questions that led you to investigate topics, whether it was planning a holiday, growing plants, fixing things at home, training a pet, or shopping online.

In college and higher education, it is expected that you will have a curious mind, identify problems and questions, critically explore and evaluate information, and create your own responses and knowledge. Some students may find this challenging because, in some cultures, knowledge is seen as fixed, and learning comes from listening to teachers and texts. It may feel disrespectful to question established knowledge and authority, and you might think you should be told what is important to learn. However, in higher education in the UK, US, much of Europe, and Australasia, questioning established knowledge and authorities is encouraged.

This process of inquiry and knowledge creation can seem overwhelming. Critical thinking is especially important in research. The research done by others is valuable for students, academics, and professionals, but we must not simply repeat what we read as if it is always true. We need to engage with it, think critically, test ideas, and determine if what we are told is logical and supported by evidence. We should avoid relying uncritically on the facts and information provided by others in our readings or discussions.

Text: 'Cities have always been centers of intellectual life, from the coffee houses of 18th-century London, where people discussed chemistry and politics, to the cafés of modern Paris, where artist Pablo Picasso talked about modern art. However, city life can be challenging. The same London cafés that encouraged discussion also helped spread diseases like cholera; Picasso eventually moved to the countryside. While modern cities can be creative places, they can also feel unnatural and overwhelming. Scientists are now studying how city life affects our brains, and the findings are concerning. It has long been known that city life is tiring, but new research shows that living in cities can actually reduce our ability to think clearly. One major reason for this is the lack of nature, which is surprisingly good for our brains. Studies have shown that hospital patients recover faster when they can see trees from their windows. Even small views of nature can improve brain function because they provide a break from the busy city life. This research comes at a time when more people than ever live in cities. Instead of living in open spaces, we are packed into concrete environments, surrounded by many strangers. Recent studies show that these unnatural surroundings can significantly affect our mental and physical health and change how we think. Think about everything your brain has to manage while walking down a busy street: distracted people, dangerous crossings that require attention to traffic, and the confusing layout of the city. These seemingly simple tasks can drain our energy because they take advantage of a weak point in our brains. Cities are filled with stimuli, so we must constantly shift our focus. This kind of attention management – deciding what to ignore and what to pay attention to – requires energy. The brain is like a powerful computer, but focusing uses a lot of its processing power. In contrast, natural environments do not demand as much mental effort. This idea is known as attention restoration theory, developed by psychologist Stephen Kaplan. It has been known for a long time that human attention is limited – focusing in the morning makes it harder to concentrate in the afternoon. Kaplan suggested that being in nature could help restore our attention. Natural settings have many things that naturally attract our focus, but they do not cause negative feelings – unlike a police siren, for example. In nature, our attention can relax and recharge. Long before scientists studied this, philosophers and landscape architects warned about the effects of city life and sought ways to include nature in urban areas. Vibrant parks, like Central Park in New York, provide a break from city life. A well-designed park can enhance brain function in just a few minutes. While people have looked for various ways to boost cognitive performance, from energy drinks to office redesigns, it seems that few methods are as effective as simply taking a walk in nature. Given the many mental challenges caused by city life, one question remains: Why do cities keep growing? And why, even in the digital age, do they continue to be sources of intellectual life? Recent research at the Santa Fe Institute showed that the same urban features that cause attention and memory problems – crowded streets and close proximity to others – are also linked to innovation. Scientists believe that the ‘concentration of social interactions’ is mainly responsible for creativity in cities. Just as the crowded environment of 18th-century London led to new ideas, the crowded nature of 21st-century Cambridge, Massachusetts, contributes to its success as a technology hub. Conversely, less crowded urban areas may produce less innovation over time. The challenge, then, is to find ways to reduce the psychological stress of city life while keeping its unique advantages. Because there will always come a time when someone will say: ‘I’m tired of nature; take me to the city!’'

Text: 'Where should we look for the mind? This may seem like a strange question: thinking happens in people’s heads, right? Today, we have advanced brain imaging techniques to support this idea. However, I believe there is no strong reason to limit the study of the mind to just the inside of our bodies. There is a lot of evidence, from ancient times to now, showing that objects, as well as our brains, play a role in how we think. From an archaeological perspective, it is clear that tools, decorations, carvings, clay tokens, and writing systems have actively contributed to human evolution and the development of our minds. Therefore, I propose that what exists outside our heads may also be part of our minds. 

It is easy to understand why we often connect the mind with the brain. Most of what we know about the human mind comes from studying people in isolation from their surroundings. This makes sense for neuroscientists, especially when using brain-scanning machines. However, this approach often overlooks the fact that much of our thinking happens outside our heads. I do not intend to deny the importance of the brain in thinking, but I want to emphasize that the mind is more than just the brain. It is more useful to explore the idea that human intelligence extends beyond our bodies into culture and the material world. This is where my new theory, Material Engagement Theory (MET), comes in. 

MET aims to investigate how objects can become extensions of our thinking or be integrated into our bodies. For example, when we create numbers and symbols from clay or use a stone to make a tool. It also looks at how these interactions have changed since ancient times and what these changes mean for our thinking. This approach provides new insights into what minds are and how they are shaped by the things around us. 

Consider a blind person using a stick. Where does this person’s self begin? The connection between the blind person and the stick helps us understand that minds and objects can be seen as interconnected. It also illustrates the flexibility of the human mind: by using the stick, the blind person transforms touch into a form of sight, while the stick itself plays an important role. The sensation felt at the tip of the stick connects the person to the environment, and the brain treats the stick as part of the body. 

The blind person’s stick reminds us that human intelligence can adapt and change significantly by incorporating new technologies. I view the human mind as an ongoing project, always evolving. It is essential to remember that, regardless of what form the ‘stick’ has taken throughout our history—whether it be ancient stone tools or modern technology—its main purpose is to connect us to the world, not to separate us from it. 

For humans, tools are used to satisfy our curiosity. This unique ability to engage with material culture explains why we create things more than any other species, and how these creations, in turn, shape our minds. I call this metaplasticity—our minds are flexible and develop as we interact with the material world. I want to reintroduce the importance of material objects in understanding cognition. MET provides a new perspective on how various forms of material culture, from ancient tools to the latest smartphones, have influenced and transformed who we are and how we think. While the idea of technology changing our minds may sound futuristic, it is important to realize that humans have been using such tools since our earliest days.'

Text: 'Few inventions have changed the course of civilization as much as photography. This is especially true in the United States, where photography quickly became part of American culture at all levels – from practical and scientific uses to industrial and aesthetic purposes, as well as a new world of entertainment that emerged with the camera. Historians argue that photography is one of the greatest contributions of the United States to the visual arts. No other art form has had such a significant impact from the US. This claim reflects the idea that photography has become central to American intellectual and artistic discussions, and to fully appreciate its impact, we must look at its beginnings in the mid-19th century.

Why was this new art form so appealing? First, photography was a mechanical process that matched a growing interest in technology, part of a national mindset that accepted change as normal. Just as steam power, railroads, and electricity made the world smaller by improving communication and travel, photography brought the wonders of the world into homes with an immediacy that was astonishing. Second, the camera became the preferred tool for representing the self, allowing individuals to create images for public viewing in a society where personal and national identities were constantly being formed and reformed. Third, the camera has been very important for creating and preserving family memories, even if these memories are somewhat idealized. Finally, the realism of photographs aligns with a trend towards realism in the work of American artists.

Every photograph draws attention to something specific, showing what the photographer wants us to see. The fact that a photograph is made by a machine, rather than drawn by hand, gives it a unique quality: photographs are records of events, people, and things; they are at least records of what was in front of the camera, which gives them a certain objectivity. However, because each photograph is taken by a specific person, it also carries a personal point of view. We might look at a photograph and think we understand its meaning because we recognize the subject, leading to the idea that photography is a 'universal language.' But the meaning of photographs is more complex than that. Few subjects – whether a person, object, or event – convey their own meaning, and no image is presented to us without some context that shapes our understanding of it, such as a caption in a newspaper or its placement in a gallery.

To understand a photograph historically, we need to consider its purpose and role within a specific cultural context: Why did the photographer take the image? How did people first see it? Additionally, the same image might be viewed in different places and times, leading to different meanings each time. While the importance of the camera to artists was not widely recognized for a long time, it is now clear to contemporary artists. For several decades, starting with U.S. artist Andy Warhol’s use of photographs in his paintings and silk screens, artists have been incorporating photographs into their work in various ways. In summary, photographic vision has become an essential part of painting in the history of art, rather than being seen as separate from it.'

In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and physician, defined psychology as the "science of mental life." This definition is still relevant today. We all have a mental life, which gives us some understanding of what this means. Although we can study mental life in animals like rats and monkeys, it remains a complex idea. James focused on human psychology, which he believed included basic elements: thoughts, feelings, a physical world that exists in time and space, and a way of knowing about these elements. Our knowledge is mostly personal and comes from our own thoughts, feelings, and experiences, which may or may not align with scientific facts. 

This personal knowledge can lead us to make judgments about psychological issues based on our own experiences. We often act as amateur psychologists when we share opinions on complex topics, such as whether brainwashing is effective or why people behave in certain ways, like feeling insulted or unhappy. Problems can arise when two people interpret situations differently. Formal psychology aims to provide methods to determine which explanations are most likely correct in a given situation. Psychologists help us differentiate between subjective thoughts, which can be biased, and objective facts.

Psychology, as defined by William James, focuses on the mind and brain. While psychologists study the brain, they do not yet fully understand how it works in relation to our hopes, fears, and behaviors. It is often difficult to study the brain directly, so psychologists learn more by observing behavior and forming hypotheses about what happens inside us. A challenge in psychology is that scientific facts should be objective, but the mind's workings are not directly observable like a machine's. Instead, they can only be inferred from behavior.

Studying psychology is similar to solving a crossword puzzle. It requires evaluating and interpreting clues, which must come from careful observation and accurate measurement. These observations need to be analyzed rigorously and interpreted logically, allowing for public scrutiny. Psychology often involves complex interactions, and understanding them requires advanced techniques and theories. Like any other science, psychology aims to describe, understand, predict, and learn how to influence the processes it studies. Achieving these goals can help us understand our experiences and apply findings to improve people's lives.

Psychological research has been beneficial in various areas, such as developing better methods for teaching children to read, designing safer machine controls, and helping emotionally distressed individuals communicate their feelings. Although psychological questions have been discussed for centuries, scientific investigation has only occurred in the last 150 years. Early psychologists used introspection, or self-reflection, to answer psychological questions. They aimed to identify mental structures, which remains a key interest today. However, introspection has limitations, as noted by Sir Francis Galton, who said it only reveals a small part of the mind's automatic processes. William James compared introspection to "turning up the gas quickly enough to see how the darkness looks." Therefore, modern psychologists prefer to base their theories on careful observations of others' behavior rather than solely on their own experiences.

Text: 'In a storehouse in a typical business park in Michigan, USA, lies a collection of failed consumer products – a contrast to the positive, success-driven culture of modern marketing. Here, you can find items like A Touch of Yogurt shampoo and Breakfast Cola, which were not popular. This collection, now owned by a company called GfK, is informally known as the Museum of Failed Products. Its exhibits are products that were taken off the market because few people wanted to buy them. The museum’s owner, Carol Sherry, believes that each product tells a sad story about the designers, marketers, and salespeople involved. What is most surprising about the museum is that it exists as a profitable business. You might think that any serious manufacturer would keep a collection of their failed products. However, the executives who visit the museum show how rare this is. They seem to avoid thinking about their failures and often do not keep samples of their unsuccessful products. The museum itself was an unexpected success. Its creator, Robert McMath, originally wanted to create a ‘reference library’ of consumer products, not just failed ones. Starting in the 1960s, he began buying samples of every new item he could find. What he did not realize was a simple truth: ‘Most products fail.’ By collecting new products without discrimination, McMath ended up with mostly unsuccessful items. Today’s culture of optimism likely contributes to the products in the museum. Each product probably went through meetings where no one recognized it would fail. Even if they did, marketers might feel pressured to invest more money into a failing product to save face. Little effort is made to understand why these products failed; everyone involved may have agreed, perhaps unknowingly, to never discuss it again. This focus on optimism is especially strong in the growing ‘self-help’ industry. A common idea here is ‘positive visualization’: if you imagine things going well, they are more likely to happen – or so the belief goes. In fact, neuroscientist Tali Sharot has found evidence that a healthy mind may be inclined to see the chances of success as better than they actually are. Her research suggests that well-adjusted people often have a less accurate and overly optimistic view of their ability to influence outcomes compared to those who are depressed. But how effective are these ‘positive fantasies about the future’? This is the question psychologist Gabriele Oettingen and her team have been exploring. Their findings are surprising: spending time thinking about how well things could go often reduces people’s motivation to reach their goals. For instance, groups of people who were encouraged to imagine having a very successful week at work ended up achieving less. Psychologist Carol Dweck believes that our experiences of failure are shaped by our beliefs about ability. Dweck explains that people with a ‘fixed mindset’ think ability is something you are born with; those with a ‘growth mindset’ believe it develops through effort and challenges. People with a fixed mindset find failure particularly frightening, seeing it as proof that they did not measure up. A common example is a sports star who thinks of himself as a ‘natural’ but fails to practice enough to reach his potential. In contrast, people with a growth mindset view failure as a sign that they are pushing their limits. Dweck compares this to weight training: muscles grow by being pushed to their limits, where they tear and heal, becoming stronger. The deeper message is that having a growth mindset is a more positive way to approach life, regardless of whether it leads to success.'

Text: 'Everyone knows that sports teams have an advantage when they play at home. But do we really understand why? Many of us think we do, as it seems obvious. However, professional sports are changing quickly, and much of what we used to believe is now being questioned. Two main factors are challenging the traditional idea of home advantage: science and money. Sports scientists want to discover what helps players perform at their best, leading to many theories about home advantage. At the same time, those in charge of finances want to know why home advantage is still important. If players are paid well, shouldn’t they feel comfortable playing anywhere?

What does this mean for fans? Would it matter if Manchester United played some home games in the Far East to reach their fans there? It would matter to British fans, who believe their team needs their support and loyalty. This may lead them to confuse cause and effect. People often think that events are best explained by the order they remember them, rather than how they actually happened. When a team attacks, home fans cheer loudly, and sometimes this leads to a goal, causing the crowd to erupt. Fans tend to remember the times they cheered and a goal was scored, forgetting the many times their cheers did not lead to success.

However, there is one common belief among fans that scientific evidence seems to support. Home fans not only cheer for their players but also direct a lot of their energy at the referee. In a well-known experiment, referees watched a match with crowd noise and another version without sound. The referees who heard the crowd were less likely to call fouls against the home team compared to those who watched in silence. Interestingly, the crowd noise did not make them more likely to call fouls against the away team. The researchers concluded that referees try to avoid extra stress from making calls against the home team. They do not simply follow the crowd’s wishes; they aim to avoid provoking the crowd’s anger.

Recent studies on home advantage have looked at long-term trends. They show that home advantage has decreased in all major sports, but not as much as expected. For example, in the early years of the Football League in the 1890s in England, home teams won about 70% of the points, compared to 60% today. One reason for this change may be travel; it used to be difficult, but now football players travel in great comfort, and if their hotel is not good enough, the club will find them a better one. Local conditions used to vary greatly, but now top stadiums are increasingly similar in their efficiency.

Despite these explanations, none fully explains the data. These changes—pampered players, modern support staff, and similar stadiums—have all happened relatively recently. The mystery remains why home advantage varies by sport. Basketball offers the greatest home advantage, followed by football, while baseball has the least. One possible reason is that home advantage is more about teamwork, and baseball focuses more on individual matchups between batter and pitcher. Team sports require coordination among teammates. In basketball, success depends on all players working together, which builds confidence in their ability to connect on the court. This confidence seems to grow from the familiarity of playing at home, regardless of the playing conditions.

There is another possibility related to a more aggressive side of sports. Researchers found that players’ testosterone levels were normal before training and away games, but increased by up to 67% before home games. This sense of defending their home may connect to a basic instinct to protect their territory, as seen in the recent Rugby World Cup. In two notable games, underdog teams won at home against stronger opponents, showing determination and aggression—clear signs of home advantage. As one referee put it, ‘It’s the law of the jungle out there.’

Text: "‘The more I practice, the luckier I get,’ said golfer Gary Player about fifty years ago. This saying is famous in sports and is appreciated by many dedicated athletes and their coaches. The quote is interesting for a couple of reasons. First, there is debate about who originally said it, as many golfers from that time have been suggested as the source. Second, its meaning is not straightforward. Player did not mean 'lucky' in a literal sense; he was being ironic. His real message was: ‘The more I practice, the better I get.’ However, there is a limit to this idea.
