The question of where that limit is, or if it even exists, relates to the nature-nurture debate, which discusses whether talent is something we are born with or something we develop through practice. 

This discussion is not balanced; it seems that nurture has won out. The idea that practice is more important than natural talent in sports, music, business, and other areas comes from psychologist Anders Ericsson. He is known for the theory that becoming an expert in any field requires 10,000 hours of practice. This theory has been popularized in books like Malcolm Gladwell’s Outliers and others with titles like Talent Is Overrated and Bounce: The Myth of Talent and the Power of Practice. These books generally agree that practice is the most important factor, suggesting that ‘10,000 hours is both necessary and sufficient to make anyone an expert in anything.’ 

However, as Epstein discusses in his engaging book, this is often not the case. He points out a major flaw in much of the research on excellence: it usually focuses only on successful individuals. He asks if there are other ways to understand why some people have certain abilities while others do not, and how to separate innate traits from those shaped by environment, support, opportunity, and determination. Epstein travels around the world, from Kenya to Sweden and the Caribbean to the Arctic, to find answers. In Alaska, he discovers that the success of sled dogs in tough races may depend on their drive and desire, suggesting a link between genetics and traits we think of as voluntary.

This raises the question: can commitment and determination be chosen, or are they influenced by genetics? Epstein believes that the case of the huskies shows that drive may have a genetic aspect. This highlights the complexity of the topic. He makes a distinction between hardware (nature) and software (nurture), agreeing that elite athletes need both. He does not deny the importance of training or environment, suggesting that if Usain Bolt had grown up in the US, he might have been a good basketball player instead of the fastest man in history. However, he also examines cases where genetics play a crucial role. He questions the issue of race and gender in sports, asking: ‘If only practice hours matter, why do we separate men and women in athletic competitions?’ Sometimes, the best questions are the most obvious."

Text: A recent international report shows that many children in wealthy countries feel lonely and unhappy. Jay Griffiths asks a simple question: why are today’s children so unhappy? In her new book, Kith, Griffiths explains that these children spend too much time indoors, stuck in front of screens, and have lost touch with nature – the woods, mountains, rivers, and streams. She believes this is the main issue. This idea matches other discussions about childhood today. A follow-up study interviewed some children to understand their feelings better. The study found that many children do not wish for more technology; instead, they would be happier if they could go outside more. Many adults over 40 remember their own childhoods fondly, recalling how they spent long summer days exploring, swimming, or building forts. They believe this was much better and healthier than the protected lives of today’s children. However, they often forget that they created this protective environment for their own kids, avoiding risks like building forts in old sheds. 

Griffiths’ book contains strong arguments. She discusses how the fear of dangers in the outside world and the focus on child-centered consumerism are connected. Parents’ fears of danger lead them to keep their children at home, which benefits the toy and gadget industry that sells entertainment for indoor kids. She also criticizes trends like prescribing medication for restless children or requiring kids to wear goggles during traditional playground games. While I am unsure how common these strict rules are, Griffiths expresses her frustration with passion, discussing various aspects of childhood freedoms and limitations, from fairy tales to school rules. 

However, Griffiths sometimes goes too far with her ideas, ignoring important counter-arguments. At one point, she even compares the modern treatment of children to a subtle form of racism, calling it “really ugly.” Part of the issue is that Griffiths has a romantic view of children. Although she acknowledges that “children can be mavericks of malice,” she mostly presents an idealized view of them that may not match reality. It would be hard to convince an average parent that, as Griffiths says, “children are the musicians of thought.” Perhaps they could be if given the chance, but I doubt it. 

One of the main themes of the book is that children should have the freedom to explore and take risks. Griffiths believes that children cannot learn to manage risks without experiencing some danger. She writes, “Children need accidents,” suggesting that small accidents help them avoid bigger ones later. However, she does not explain how to create these “right size” accidents. Also, do all children really want to follow the adventurous model Griffiths admires? What about the naturally shy, cautious, or home-loving children? Perhaps the real issue is that we try to fit all children into the same mold, whether by keeping them indoors or pushing them outside.

Text: "I am a research bio-psychologist with a PhD, which means I have studied a lot. I am good at solving problems in my work and life, but this skill is not just from my education. Many life problems cannot be solved with complicated formulas or memorized answers learned in school. They need judgment, wisdom, and creativity that come from life experiences. For children, these experiences often happen through play. 

My recent research focuses on the importance of play for children's development. All mammals, including humans, play when they are young, and those that have the most to learn tend to play the most. Carnivores play more than herbivores because hunting is harder to learn than grazing. Primates play more than other mammals because they rely more on learning than on instinct. Children, who have the most to learn, play more than any other young primates when they are allowed to. 

Play is a natural way for adults and mammals to educate themselves. The most important skills children need to live happy and productive lives cannot be taught in school. These skills are learned and practiced through play. They include the ability to think creatively, get along with others, cooperate effectively, and control their impulses and emotions. Creativity is essential for success in today’s economy. We no longer need people who simply follow instructions or perform routine calculations. Instead, we need people who can ask new questions and solve new problems. 

If we can encourage creative thinkers who can foresee challenges, we will create a strong workforce. However, this requires a creative mindset, which is often linked to playfulness. Adults we call geniuses are those who maintain and develop their childlike creativity throughout their lives. For example, Albert Einstein said that school almost destroyed his interest in math and physics, but he regained it after leaving school. He described his innovative work as ‘combinatorial play’ and said he developed his theory of relativity by imagining himself chasing a sunbeam.

We cannot teach creativity, but we can stifle it through schooling that focuses on fixed questions rather than children’s own inquiries. Even more important than creativity is the ability to connect with others, care for them, and cooperate. Children naturally want to play with others, and through play, they learn social skills, fairness, and morality, which are essential for their future. 

Play is voluntary, meaning players can choose to stop at any time. If you cannot quit, it is not play. Players understand that to keep the game enjoyable, they must keep others happy. This freedom makes play a very democratic activity. 

However, school has become more demanding: breaks are shorter, homework is heavier, and there is more pressure for high grades. Outside of school, adult-led sports have taken the place of spontaneous games. ‘Play dates’ with adult supervision have replaced unsupervised neighborhood play, and adults often feel they must intervene instead of allowing children to solve their own problems. 

These changes have happened slowly but have had a significant impact over time. They are caused by various social factors, including parents’ fears, warnings from experts about dangers, the decline of close-knit neighborhoods, and the belief that children learn more from adults than from each other. 

Our children do not need more school; they need more play. If we care about our children and future generations, we must change the negative trend of the past fifty years. We must give childhood back to children. They should be allowed to follow their natural instincts to play and explore, so they can grow into strong adults ready for an unpredictable future."

In many countries, more young people in their twenties are using social media to find jobs. Websites like Twitter and LinkedIn allow them to connect directly with potential employers, which is a new way to get noticed compared to the old method of standing outside an office with a sign saying "hire me." However, this increased access also means there is a higher risk of making mistakes. 

For example, a young job seeker in the US reached out to a senior marketing executive on LinkedIn. This executive had many influential contacts, and the job seeker thought she could help him find a job. However, the executive was offended by the idea of sharing her contacts with someone she didn’t know. She rejected his request and sent a harsh and sarcastic message that quickly spread online. Many people were shocked by her response, and she might regret her tone, if not her message. 

This incident highlights an important point: social media can be risky for job seekers who do not know how to use it properly. Unfortunately, many young people are making mistakes. Ironically, social networking sites like Facebook and Twitter have been central to the social lives of young people for years. When older generations were teenagers, social media was a way to escape from parents and teachers. It was a place to impress others and create a different identity. 

However, using social media for professional networking is very different. For some young people, the line between personal and professional use is not clear. Many of them built their online presence by being bold and confident, which may lead them to think this approach is still appropriate. Just because many people liked your posts on Facebook does not mean you can use LinkedIn to show employers you are a good candidate. 

Young job seekers need to understand that the social networking skills they learned as teenagers do not apply in the professional world. They must meet employers’ expectations to succeed in their careers. One common complaint from employers is that young job seekers are too casual in their communication and come across as arrogant. This reinforces the stereotype of young people as an "entitled generation." In reality, many young people are struggling to find jobs, which is why they are using social media.

To contact someone on a professional networking site correctly, you should first clearly introduce yourself and explain what you can offer them, such as doing research or helping in another way. This approach increases your chances of receiving a helpful response. Avoid sending generic messages, and keep your tone respectful to leave a positive impression. Remember, social media can be a valuable tool for making connections, but it requires careful use to avoid negative outcomes.

Text: "Anyone who claims they can accurately predict the future of newspapers is either lying or mistaken. The numbers show that newspapers are in trouble. Since 2000, the circulation of most UK national daily newspapers has dropped by one-third to one-half. The Pew Research Centre in the USA reports that newspapers are now the main source of news for only 26% of US citizens, down from 45% in 2001. Many people confidently predict that the last printed newspaper will be gone within 15 years. However, history shows that old media often survive. In 1835, a New York journalist claimed that books and theatre were finished and that the daily newspaper would become the most important source of news. Yet, theatre survived not only the newspaper but also cinema and television. Radio has thrived in the age of TV, and cinema has continued to do well against videos and DVDs. Even vinyl records have made a comeback, with online sales increasing by 745% since 2008. Newspapers were once a new form of media, and it took centuries for them to become the main source of news. This was not only because producing timely news for a large audience became possible in the mid-19th century with the steam press, railways, and telegraphs, but also because people began to understand that everything around them is always changing and that they need regular updates. In medieval times, people did not think this way; they only recognized the changing seasons and unexpected disasters like famine or disease. Life was, as writer Alain de Botton describes, 'inevitably cyclical,' with important truths repeating. Before the 19th century, journalism as a profession where one could earn a living hardly existed. Even then, there was no clear reason why most people needed news regularly, whether daily or weekly. In some ways, the regular publication of newspapers and their fixed format can be limiting. Online news allows readers to choose when to read based on the urgency of events. Advanced search engines and algorithms help us customize news according to our interests. When major stories happen, online news providers can give updates almost instantly. Mistakes and misunderstandings can be corrected quickly. There are no space limits that restrict storytelling or analysis, and readers can often access full documents or events mentioned in news articles. This is very different from the limitations of newspaper publishing. Yet, few news providers seem to recognize the potential of the internet to enhance understanding. Instead, the focus is often on being the first to report news, increasing reader comments, and creating excitement, which can lead to confusion. In medieval times, news was often shared in busy marketplaces or taverns, where truth competed with rumors and misunderstandings. In some ways, we seem to be returning to that environment. Newspapers have never been very effective at explaining how the world works. They may be facing extinction. Or perhaps, as the internet adds to our feeling that we live in 'an unchangeable and fundamentally chaotic universe,' newspapers will find that they alone can help guide us to wisdom and understanding."

Text: 'If humans truly felt at home under the moon and stars, we would walk in the dark happily, just like many night-active animals that thrive in it. However, we are daytime creatures, with eyes designed for sunlight. This fact is deeply rooted in our genetics, even if we don’t often think of ourselves as daytime beings, just as we don’t think of ourselves as primates or mammals. Yet, this is the only way to understand what we have done to the night. We have changed the night by filling it with artificial light. This control is similar to building a dam on a river. While it has benefits, it also brings problems known as light pollution, which scientists are just starting to study. Light pollution mainly comes from poor lighting design that allows artificial light to shine into the sky instead of focusing it down where it is needed. Bad lighting brightens the night, changing the light levels and rhythms that many life forms, including us, have adapted to. Wherever artificial light spreads into nature, it affects various life activities like migration, reproduction, and feeding. 

For most of human history, the term ‘light pollution’ would not have made sense. Imagine walking towards London on a moonlit night around 1800, when it was the most populated city on Earth. Nearly a million people lived there, using candles, torches, and lanterns. Only a few homes had gas lighting, and there were no public gaslights in the streets for another seven years. From a distance, you would have been more likely to smell London than to see its faint glow. We have illuminated the night as if it were empty, but that is far from the truth. Among mammals, the number of night-active species is incredible. Light is a strong biological force that attracts many species. The effect is so strong that scientists say songbirds and seabirds can be ‘captured’ by searchlights or gas flares, circling endlessly until they fall. Birds that migrate at night often crash into brightly lit tall buildings, and young birds on their first journey are especially affected. Some birds, like blackbirds and nightingales, sing at odd hours because of artificial light.

It was once believed that light pollution only impacted astronomers, who need to see the night sky clearly. Unlike astronomers, most of us may not need a perfect view of the night sky for our work, but we, like many other creatures, do need darkness. Rejecting darkness is pointless. It is as important for our biological health as light is; changing our internal clock can lead to various health issues. The regular cycle of waking and sleeping is a biological reflection of the light changes on Earth. These rhythms are so essential to our existence that disrupting them is like changing our center of gravity. In the end, humans are just as affected by light pollution as frogs living near a brightly lit road. By living in our own created glare, we have disconnected ourselves from our evolutionary and cultural roots – the light of the stars and the natural rhythms of day and night. In a very real way, light pollution makes us forget our true place in the universe and the scale of our existence, which is best understood against the backdrop of a deep night with the Milky Way – the edge of our galaxy – shining above us.'

Text: 'The founder of a large international company recently announced that his business would stop tracking how much paid holiday time employees take. This decision seems to have been inspired by a similar policy from an internet company. The founder mentioned that he got the idea from a cheerful email from his daughter, which many newspapers have shared. However, this way of announcing the change feels like a superficial attempt to make a potentially unkind policy seem friendlier. 

Is this idea practical? The internet company and the multinational corporation are very different. The internet company has 2,000 employees and offers one service, while the multinational has 50,000 employees and many different services, including finance, transport, and healthcare. The idea of "take as much time off as you want, as long as it doesn’t hurt the business" seems more suitable for a smaller company where employees know each other’s workloads better. In a large company, it is hard to know if taking time off will affect the business or their careers. 

The founder has said that employees can take as much leave as they want, as long as they feel completely sure that their team is up to date on all projects and that their absence won’t harm the business. But can anyone be that sure? No matter how much work you finish before a holiday, there will always be more waiting when you return. This is just how taking leave works; you pause your work, but it keeps building up. Employees who follow these guidelines might not take any leave at all, or they might feel guilty about taking time off. This guilt can lead to stress, and if workers don’t take enough leave, it could reduce productivity over time. 

There may also be pressure from colleagues and office gossip about who is taking time off and for how long. This pressure can already influence when people start and finish their workday. In many companies, especially in corporate settings, there is a culture of working late, which could lead to a "no holiday" culture in a place with unlimited leave, where employees compete for promotions. If the security and rights that come with statutory leave are taken away, workers might feel they cannot take the time off they need for fear of being seen as lazy. They would lose their legal right to rely on. 

This policy could create a situation where employees feel unable to take their entitled leave, or they might continue to use their legal rights as a guideline, making the new policy ineffective. Modern technology allows us to receive work messages anytime and anywhere, which has blurred the line between work and personal time. The internet company started their unlimited leave policy when employees asked how this new way of working could fit with the old time-off policy. If the employer can’t track how much time employees spend working, why should they use an outdated standard for time off? 

However, a problem with having no set working hours is that all hours could become working hours. Employees might never know if their working hours are being watched by their employer, leading them to feel they must self-discipline, which can have negative effects. Employment laws exist for a reason. Workers have the right to a minimum amount of paid annual leave because rest and leisure are essential for their mental and physical health. The increased morale, creativity, and productivity that are expected from the unlimited leave policy can exist without considering worker well-being. Therefore, I am skeptical that allowing employees to "take as much holiday as they want" is truly the intention or likely result of this policy.'

Text: 'Journal-based peer review is the process of having a scientific research paper examined by experts in the same field. It is often seen as a way to ensure the quality of research. This process is said to filter out flawed or nonsensical papers, and scientists often mention it positively when speaking to the media or the public. However, reviewing a paper can delay its publication by up to a year. Is this delay worth it to ensure the trustworthiness of published research? The answer is both yes and no. Examining these issues reveals much about the current state of scientific publishing, which is changing rapidly. 

I am not ready to completely abandon journal-based peer review. I still believe that all papers should go through some form of checking before they are published. However, I sense a shift happening. The increasing use of preprints—drafts of papers shared online without peer review—plays a significant role in this change. Preprints allow researchers to quickly share new findings so that others can read, critique, and build upon them. 

Publishing in journals has become more about gaining recognition and advancing careers, which has affected both authors' motivations and reviewers' roles. The competition for publication in prestigious journals encourages scientists to produce high-quality work, and these journals do publish excellent research. However, the rewards for publishing in top journals can lead to shortcuts, as stories that omit inconvenient data are more likely to be accepted. Reviewers now often focus on whether a manuscript is good enough for a specific journal rather than its overall quality. For top journals, this can depend more on relevance or newsworthiness than on scientific merit.

These issues are well-known, but few are willing to change the current system. However, as biologist Ron Vale recently argued in a preprint, preprints might offer a solution because they do not require a major change from the existing system. Although preprint archives have existed for twenty years, they have not been widely adopted. This slow acceptance reflects scientists' conservative nature and the misconception that journals will not accept manuscripts that have been posted as preprints. There is also concern that publishing papers without peer review could lead to 'junk science,' but this has not happened so far.

While preprints are not peer-reviewed, authors understand that they are open to critique and discussion from a global community of reviewers. Tanya Elks, a psychology professor, shares her experience: ‘My paper critiqued a published paper, which traditional journals do not handle well. In their anonymous peer review system, the original authors might block a critical paper, or if they are not chosen as reviewers, they might complain about misrepresentation. By posting a preprint, the original authors could respond, and we could consider their feedback. All comments are public, allowing readers to assess the quality of the arguments. The risk of rejection by journals is less concerning since we still have the preprint and public comments, ensuring our work is not wasted.’

Preprint archives facilitate informal scientific discussions that were once limited to individual correspondence. They can also serve as a valuable platform for sharing negative results, which are often overlooked by journals focused on new discoveries. Additionally, being on preprint archives significantly increases the number of times papers are read and cited, demonstrating the effectiveness of sharing research this way. By embracing the web's culture of openness and collaboration, preprints can help shift the focus back to the quality of the work itself, rather than where it is published.'

Text: 'When I ask my literature students what a poem is, I often hear answers like "a painting in words." These answers usually do not satisfy me or the students. One day, I asked a group to choose an object and write one paragraph describing it like a scientist would, and another paragraph from the object's point of view, titled "Poem." One student wrote: 

Poem 
I may look strange or scary, but I’m a device that helps people breathe. I’m only used in emergencies and for a short time. Most people will never need to use me. The item? An oxygen mask – an unusual choice that helped the class understand how poetry works in a unique way. This exercise led to laughter and helpful discussion. 

When I was in school, poetry often seemed confusing to me. I viewed every poem as a silly puzzle that made it hard to understand and feel. After school, poetry tends to attract less attention from most people. Sometimes you see a poem, and it stands out because it is not continuous prose. It challenges you to read it, but often you feel let down by its simplicity or because it is hard to understand at first. Still, you feel proud for trying. 

What do we hope to find in the poems we read? Isn’t a poem a place for deep feelings, beautiful images, thoughtful reflections, or sharp humor? The answer seems to be yes. But if we want tears, we watch movies; for information or sharp criticism, we read online articles. Novels let us escape, paintings please our eyes, and music – well, nothing can compare to that perfect mix of lyrics, instruments, and melody. 

However, one useful aspect of a poem is its ambiguity. Everyday life is full of ambiguity, unlike reading sentence by sentence. But these thoughts still do not explain what a poem really is. If you search online for "poem," it leads you to "poetry": "a form of literary art that uses the beauty and rhythm of language." This sounds good, but it misses the word's origins. "Poem" comes from the Greek word poí?ma, meaning "a thing made," and a poet is a "maker of things." So if a poem is a thing made, what kind of thing is it? 

Poets sometimes compare poems to wild animals – untameable and unpredictable – or to machines – carefully designed and precise – depending on their perspective. But these comparisons often break down upon closer examination. The most valuable part of trying to define a poem through comparison is not the comparison itself but the discussion it creates. Whether you see a poem as a machine or a wild animal, this process can change how you think about machines or wild animals. It can help us rethink our usual ways of thinking and see ordinary things in a new way. 

The idea of a poem as a mental object is not hard to grasp, especially when we think about how song lyrics can stick in our minds. The mix of words and melody has a power that goes back to schoolyard rhymes like "Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words can never hurt me." But aren’t words sometimes like sticks and stones? Think about a poem on a page of a newspaper or magazine, right in front of you: A poem can resonate deeply like nothing else, even though, on paper, it does the same as the prose around it. 

What about all that empty space around the poem – space that could have been used for a longer article or advertisement? A poem is created through writing and rewriting, just like an article, story, or novel, yet it never fully becomes what they usually are – a product meant to be sold. Publishers write press releases and send out review copies of poetry collections, but few expect a collection to pay for itself. A poem presents itself not as a product for sale, but as something valuable in its own right. Because of its unique status – set apart in a magazine or book – a poem still has the power to surprise, even if just for a moment.'

Text: 'I bought my first metal detector soon after I got married. £70 was a lot of money back then, and it might have been better spent on something practical for our home. However, my wife, Marion, was impressed when I found a gold ring worth £80 on my first outing. Over the years, every brooch and coin I discovered brought me joy. I have always enjoyed feeling connected to the past. But after the gold ring, it took 40 years before I found something that impressed Marion as much. 

One dull February afternoon, I had a couple of hours free and a place in mind to search. It was raining, so I chose a closer spot that I knew had mostly old farming equipment. When my detector first beeped, I found a piece of a metal wheel. Then, it beeped again. I tried to ignore it, but I couldn’t walk away without checking. I dug down half a meter and was lying in the mud when I saw a rounded, golden ball. I had found brass curtain rails before, so I tried not to get my hopes up. But as I cleared more dirt away, the ball turned into a thick, beautifully designed loop. I stopped and stared, remembering to breathe. I had seen something like this before - the Great Torc, which is in the British Museum. It’s the most famous object from Iron Age Britain, over 2,000 years ago. A torc is a beautiful necklace made of gold and silver, with a gold ring at each end, just like the one I was looking at. 

I took it to my car. At every stoplight on the way home, I looked at the torc on the passenger seat. I rinsed it in my kitchen sink, probably the only cleaning it had since ancient times. ‘Marion!’ I called out, ‘I have something for you.’ While still looking at my find, I heard my wife come into the room and stop. ‘What is it?’ she asked after a moment. I told her it was a very old and rare piece of jewelry. We didn’t try it on because we were worried about damaging it. At bedtime, I hid it in our wardrobe. We had never been robbed, but I felt anxious. Eventually, I got up, unscrewed a floorboard in my office, and hid it underneath. 

The law says that such finds must be reported to the authorities within 14 days. I wanted to enjoy the torc as much as I could before giving it up. I even took it in a plastic bag to show a friend in the hospital. Finally, I brought it to the council office in the same bag. The registrar was talking to someone with his back to me when I placed the torc on his desk. He turned around, still talking, and then stopped. The torc was confirmed as authentic and was eventually sold to my local council. It is now in the British Museum in London. The £350,000 from the sale was shared between the owner of the field and me. But the torc means more to me than just a lucky find. I feel like I have saved it for the nation. People often say to me, ‘Now that you’ve made such a great find, will you stop detecting?’ But those brooches and coins are still interesting to me. Besides, if a fisherman catches a big fish, he doesn’t stop fishing - not while there’s a chance of catching an even bigger one tomorrow.'

Text: "Sleeping is one of my greatest joys when I travel, but I don’t often talk about it because I feel a bit guilty. When my friends share details of their carefully planned trips, where every moment is filled with activities like visiting museums and hiking, I smile and don’t say much. What would they think if they knew that my travel plans include long naps during afternoon rainstorms and lazy mornings in comfortable beds? Better sleep is one of the nice benefits of traveling. When I visited Mexico's Yucatán coast in my early 20s, I was surprised by how many hours—more than 12—I spent sleeping each day. There were many loud birds nearby, but it didn’t bother me. Far from home, surrounded by new smells and sounds, I could enjoy a deeper, more dream-filled sleep than I ever expected. Without alarm clocks and responsibilities, sleep comes more easily. However, I believe that the quality of sleep while traveling is different for another reason. I think sleep is actually part of our travel experience, not just a break from it. When we travel, we expose ourselves to new sights, sounds, smells, and ways of living. We take in many new things—cultures, music, landscapes, and even different ways of moving. It is during sleep that we process this flood of new experiences. It makes sense that sleep feels more intense when we are traveling. Sleep also changes in rhythm from place to place. People often worry about jet lag, but I think the challenges I face after long trips are more about adjusting to local cultures than about time zones. For instance, on the Caribbean island of Trinidad, people wake up at dawn to start their day before it gets too hot, slow down around 10 a.m. when the sun is high, and then become active again in the cool evening. Even though Trinidad is only one hour ahead of New York, my home, it still takes me days to adjust to the island’s different sleep patterns. When I finally adapt to the local sleep schedule, I feel like I have truly arrived. I remember one afternoon in Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic, when I had a large lunch with new Dominican friends in an apartment overlooking the blue Caribbean Sea. After the meal, feeling full and hot, our conversation faded and eventually stopped. One by one, my friends left the table to lie down on hammocks and sofas. I realized why my hosts had so many pillows on the floor. I took a couple for myself and followed their lead. I had always heard about the Latin American tradition of the siesta, but that day I truly experienced it. I shared not just sleep, but a piece of Dominican life. Travel sleep has another wonderful quality: it is memorable. Away from my usual sleep routine, I find joy in the new smells, textures, and sounds that fill my mind while I sleep in a new place. If a commitment to ‘slow travel’—enjoying every moment instead of rushing to do everything—is what defines the modern traveler, then what is slower than sleep? Maybe I should stop feeling embarrassed about my habits and be honest with my ambitious friends, explaining that travel sleep is, in fact, an activity too."

The woman turned away from the mirror. “What do you think? Be honest.” Mia picked up a medium-sized hat, soft with a layer of gauze and decorated with a silk bow. “I still think this one looks best on you,” she said diplomatically. The woman wrinkled her nose and scrunched her face, making her look like a bulldog. “But it’s so boring,” she said. “Every other woman will wear a hat like that at my daughter’s wedding. This little beauty will make me stand out.” She patted the red and black miniature top hat on her head. “Yes,” she said firmly, “this is the one I want.” Mia knew she had lost this argument. With a smile, she agreed that the woman would indeed stand out at her daughter’s wedding. She thought of her own daughter, Jen. Today was Jen’s thirtieth birthday, and they were having a family gathering. It had been a while since they had all been together, and Mia was excited to see Jen, Dan, and Luke. She was also looking forward to meeting Jen’s friend, Tattie, whom they knew nothing about. When Jen had called last week to ask if she could bring Tattie, her husband Jeff had quickly pointed out, “What kind of name is that?” “It’s short for Tatiana,” Mia replied. “I think it’s nice.” “More like something very pretentious,” Jeff said. He did not like pretentiousness or anything showy. He also did not believe in “pussyfooting around,” as he called Mia’s hesitation to speak her mind. He would have told the woman in the shop that she was choosing the wrong hat and probably would have said that a dustbin lid would look better on her. “The trouble with you, Mia,” he often said, “is that you’re too polite for your own good.” 

An hour later, Mia had closed her shop and was entering through the back door of Medlar House; her commute took only forty seconds. Four years ago, when Luke, their youngest child, left home, Mia had the idea to convert the unused barn next to the house into a bright space for her business. Jeff had been skeptical. “Do you really think there’s a demand for hats?” he asked. Mia knew from her friends that finding the perfect hat for special occasions was difficult, so she was sure there was a demand. She was right. From the first day, after Jen helped her create a website, Mia’s Hats became a success. Women came from far and wide to her showroom in Little Pelham, where she provided a relaxed environment for them to try on as many hats as they needed. With changing rooms available, she encouraged customers to bring their outfits to ensure a perfect match. Recently, she had expanded her business to include handbags and costume jewelry as well.

Text: 'It’s a long journey from London to Atlanta, and at his new home in America, Lawrence Okoye reflects on his incredible sports journey. He is confident but seems surprised by how far he has come, from competing in an Olympic final in discus to possibly starting a new chapter in his career. Although he has never played American football before, Lawrence is likely to be chosen for one of the major teams in the USA. In Atlanta, he is still figuring out the responsibilities of his new position. The idea that a 21-year-old beginner from London could be selected for one of the biggest teams in American sports is surprising. However, Lawrence is known for proving doubters wrong. After receiving an offer to study law at Oxford University, he decided to focus on training for discus instead, having previously played rugby. Within 20 months of starting, he became the world’s fourth-best discus thrower.

Lawrence originally went to Atlanta for warm-weather training for discus, preparing for the world championships. When asked about his sudden interest in a potential NFL contract, he confirms, ‘American football was in my mind, but I only decided to try it when I got to the USA. I had thought about it in school, but it seemed crazy then.’ Soon after arriving in America, he learned about the NFL trials in Atlanta. Did he think he would be good enough to attend the trials, even without any experience? ‘Pretty much,’ he replies. ‘I went on the website and applied.’ 

Was he nervous about competing with experienced American football players? ‘No,’ he says. ‘I don’t get nervous for many things.’ Although he is not very talkative, he is confident in his abilities. The statistics he provided during tests showed that he was the most impressive player. ‘I was very happy to hear that,’ he admits, showing a rare sign of pride. However, he is also cautious. With no experience, how can he make it onto an NFL team? ‘Coaches have told me I have the right skills. It’s all about how hard I work,’ he answers.

Will he be relaxed while waiting to hear if he has been selected? ‘I will be. There’s no pressure on me. Many people say I will definitely be chosen, but I’m not too worried.’ This calmness may come from his disappointing Olympic final, where he finished last. He seems to have moved on from that experience and is proud that he qualified for the final with a great last throw. ‘That was an amazing day,’ he says. ‘The final didn’t go as I wanted, but that’s part of sports. I can always return to it.’

After his Olympic disappointment, some speculated that he let the experience affect him. Lawrence chooses not to comment on that. The minimum salary for an NFL player is over $400,000 a year, so the financial reasons are clear. Lawrence has moved from rugby to athletics and now to American football. With all his physical talents, wouldn’t it be better to focus on just one sport? ‘I understand why someone would say that,’ he replies. ‘I’m trying to achieve something I’ve dreamed about since I was a kid. If it doesn’t work out, I can go back to discus, the sport I love. Every decision I’ve made has been thought out.’

Text: 'We had been flying east all night, and I woke up to see that it was already daylight. Looking out of the window at the empty landscape below, the dark shades of brown and green reassured me that, even though it was mid-September, it had not yet started to change in Siberia. I could see no signs of human life, and the view stretched out in a strange mix of mountains, streams, and forests to an endless horizon. I shook my head. My neighbor woke up and smiled sleepily at me. “Good morning, Robert,” he said, pronouncing my name with a slow, Russian accent. Sergei was a salesman from Moscow who was flying to the remote areas to sell safety clothing to local mining companies. His English was almost as poor as my Russian, but with the help of a dictionary, I managed to explain that I was flying to the far-eastern Siberian city of Magadan with a one-way ticket because I planned to return home to England by bicycle. “But, Robert,” he reasoned, “there is no road from Magadan; you cannot ride a bicycle.” I explained that I believed there was a road, though not many people used it these days. “Alone?” he asked, pointing at me. “No, I will be riding with a friend named Al.” “Just one friend?” “Yes, just one,” I nodded. Sergei still looked unconvinced and with one word, “Holodna” (cold), he pointed outside. I tried to support my case by explaining to Sergei with hand gestures that I had a lot of warm clothes, though I left out the fact that, because my trip was self-funded, I was on a tight budget. Most of my clothes and equipment had been bought at low prices. In reality, I was not sure they would be good enough. This was especially true of my large postman’s over-trousers, which I had bought for £10. 

It all started in a lecture hall in Scotland. The hall that morning was full of students slumped in their seats. Some were taking notes without much energy. The lecturer droned on. I was thinking hard about a particular dilemma. Should I ask him or not? “Well, why not?” I tore a fresh sheet from my pad and wrote, “Hi Al, Do you want to cycle across the Karakorum Highway between Pakistan and China this summer? Rob.” In the row in front of me slouched Al, my old school friend. I tapped him on the shoulder and passed the note. He tried to read my handwriting, scratched his head, wrote something, and passed it back. I unfolded it and held my breath while I read. “OK,” it said. It was six years later that I was going to join Al in Siberia. I had been working as a geography teacher, and although I was still far from having full control of my classes, the job did meet many important needs for me. It was often challenging, rarely boring, often fulfilling, and, of course, there were long holidays to chase adventures. Twice since I started teaching, I had used these holidays to meet Al. He had caught the adventuring bug after our bike ride through Pakistan and decided to do something more relaxing than teaching: to cycle around the world. Ever since that first ride together, Al had been setting himself greater challenges. This round-the-world bike trip was certainly his biggest so far. At times he thought that the ride would break him. Although it sounded tough, I envied him in many ways. He was having an extraordinary adventure, finding that he could handle each new challenge, even if it seemed impossible. He was proving wrong the skeptics who had told him he could not do it. He was doing something that scared him nearly every day, and it made him feel alive.'

In The Red Bull Air Race, twelve pilots take turns racing through pylons that are between 15 and 25 meters high. They make sharp turns, barrel rolls, and loops while flying at speeds of up to 370 km per hour. I was invited to experience what it feels like to participate. An hour before my flight, I had to sign two forms. The first confirmed that I was healthy, and the second stated that I would empty my pockets, as small objects can be dangerous during the flight. I learned that I needed to stay oriented throughout the experience. “The horizon is your best friend,” I was told, and the pilot would guide me on where to look. I was also asked to promise that when I was upside down, I would “completely relax and try to enjoy the view.” 

Half an hour before the flight, I attended a safety briefing where I was told not to touch anything. As we began taxiing down the runway, my legs were up in front of me, my feet avoiding the important steering pedals, and my hands staying away from the many switches within reach. Despite the instructions, I found it hard to relax and enjoy the flight. This is the challenge of high-speed acrobatic flying: to survive without passing out, you must stay calm and focused. You need to tense up and relax at the right times, and panicking is not a good idea. 

As we accelerated down the runway, I felt nervous. Dario, the pilot, and I were in the Zivko Edge 540, one of the fastest acrobatic planes in the world, ready to take off. The plane lifted off, and two seconds later, we sharply turned to the right. It was a sudden, intense movement, and I felt the air rush out of my lungs. I looked at the horizon, tensed my body, and gasped as I sank into my seat. For a brief moment, I felt 6.2 times my normal weight. Then we leveled out, turned sharply left, and dived, leaving my stomach behind at 2,000 meters. Seconds later, we were just 10 meters off the ground, heading for a small space between two pylons. We passed them at 400 km per hour, but my moment of excitement was interrupted by another sharp turn. 

For two minutes, I was allowed to fly the plane, but my hand shook so much that the plane shook too. Then Dario said something, and I asked him to repeat it. Instead of answering, he performed a barrel roll, a full 360-degree turn. “Are you okay?” he asked. “Yup.” “Have you had enough?” “No,” I lied. Then he did a loop, flying up and over, completing a full circle in the air. I know many people would find this thrilling, like those who enjoy roller coasters. However, I thought it was a bit overwhelming. At the top of the loop, while upside down, I heard a small voice saying, “Relax, relax, look up.” I looked up and saw some fields. The flight lasted 10 minutes and felt “soft” compared to what the pilots experience during races. To illustrate this, Dario pulled out some sandwiches as soon as we landed and happily started eating. I didn’t eat for hours, and that night, I kept dreaming about doing loops in my sleep.

Text: 'Doug Allan films wild animals in cold places. If you have ever been impressed by videos of polar bears in a nature documentary, it is likely that he filmed them. His ideal temperature, he says, is -18°C. Allan trained as a marine biologist and commercial diver. Diving was his first love, where he learned how to survive in cold environments. His big opportunity came when a TV crew arrived in Antarctica, where Allan was working, to film a wildlife documentary. "I ended up taking the crew to different locations, and after 48 hours I realized that being a wildlife cameraman was perfect for me: travel, adventure, underwater," he explains. He is now a leading cameraman and has worked on many important TV wildlife series. "I started at a good time. When I began, very few people had been to Antarctica. There were people who focused on coral, elephants, and chimpanzees. I became known as the cold man. It felt like all these amazing scenes were just waiting to be filmed." The camera and communication technology were very basic when he started 35 years ago. "It is definitely easier to film today. If you filmed something back then, you had to remember it. Now, with digital technology, you can shoot a lot and see it right away. You had to think about what shots you needed next and what you had missed. You filmed less because film was very expensive. Today, you can have too much footage." "My strength is my experience in cold conditions. I have spent so much time on sea ice that it now feels as easy as crossing the street. I do get cold toes, but the poles are healthy places. There are no leeches, diseases, or mosquitoes." Wildlife filming, Allan says, has many successes, but also failures and embarrassing moments. Once, he was in the Orkneys to film kittiwakes, but he could not identify which birds they were. Recently, when Allan got permission to film for a major TV series in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean, he knew it would not be easy. It is a place of polar bears and is only for the bravest or most reckless. Usually -32°C in April, the wind is harsh, and carrying cameras through deep snow is very difficult. After walking five or more hours a day and watching polar bear dens in the snow for 23 days, Allan had only seen one mother bear and her cub. However, by day 24, he felt like he was living in the world of bears, moving at their speed and using their senses. "We find a new hole and wait. We shuffle, hop, bend, stretch, and run to stay warm. After five hours of watching, suddenly I catch a glimpse that I almost miss. But the camera is focused on the hole, and my eye is quickly on the viewfinder. Nothing for a couple of seconds, and then I see an unmistakable black nose. The nose becomes a muzzle, then a full head, and in less than a minute, she has her front legs out and is resting on the snow in front of the hole. She looks at me but is not worried. I just pulled back from a close-up, thinking it can't get much better, when she slides down the slope. I would swear it’s partly for fun," he recalls, adding that two cubs then appeared at the den entrance. "Clearly, it’s their first view of the world. It’s showtime on the slopes, and we have front-row seats." Now, Allan wants to make his own film about climate change in the Arctic, talking to the people who live there and experience its effects firsthand. He believes he could create an extraordinary documentary.'

In 2004, Pen Hadow became the first person to walk to the North Pole alone without getting supplies along the way. This journey involved swimming in extremely cold waters and facing dangers like frostbite and polar bears. Just eight months later, he reached the South Pole as well. Now, he is back in the Arctic, getting ready for an even more ambitious expedition. Explorers are confident and determined people, and this time, there is much more at stake. Pen and two colleagues will embark on a three-month, 1,000-kilometre trek to the North Pole, where they will take detailed measurements of the ice's thickness and density. No one has done this before, and Pen understands that the results will be very important for scientists. This will provide a clearer picture of how global warming is affecting the ice in the polar regions.

Pen was prepared for this work from a young age. He was raised by his father's old nanny, who had worked for the famous polar explorer, Scott of the Antarctic. She toughened him up by sending him out into the Scottish mountains during storms with minimal clothing. His father also inspired his love for adventure in cold places, and Pen developed strong physical endurance. He is married to Mary, a horsewoman who shares his passion for the outdoors. She helps run his polar guide business and worries more about him when he is at home, saying, "He’s in more danger driving along the A303 because I know that in his head he’s somewhere in the Arctic." For fun, Mary once raced against him in a well-known mountain event where horseback riders compete against runners. She and her horse finished an hour ahead of Pen.

Pen and Mary live in the countryside with their two children. He admits, "It’s much harder to be away from them this time." When he last left, his children were one and five years old, and he made a mistake in how he said goodbye. He told his son, "You’re the man of the house now, look after your mum and your sister." His son took this seriously and often asked his mother how she was, but the pressure became too much for him. Although Pen meant well, he realizes it was unfair. For this trip, he plans to have very little contact with his family while in the Arctic, saying, "If you call them, you remind them how far away you are." In the days before he leaves, he is carefully preparing his equipment. He explains, "Out on the ice, it’s almost impossible to fix things or do anything complicated."

Joining him will be Ann Daniels, a leading polar explorer, and the expedition photographer, Martin Hartley. They will have a support crew of six people who will fly in supplies. Pen finds being part of a team more stressful, and he is also concerned about his upcoming birthday. "I’m going to be 47 on Thursday. I’ve done much less training than I’m comfortable with," he says. He feels that organizing the expedition has taken priority over his training, making him anxious about what he will face.

Pen believes his mission connects exploration with the quest for knowledge that motivated earlier explorers. He admits, "Reaching the North Pole was mainly a personal goal and of limited value to anyone outside the polar adventure community. This time, scientists will benefit from the data we collect, and we want to involve as many people as possible in understanding what is happening in the Arctic Ocean. This is important work, and only we can do it," he states. "Our skills, which may seem strange and unnecessary in everyday life, have become very relevant. Suddenly, we are useful to society again."

Text: 'I took a year off. What was I going to do? Being a successful Olympian is a wonderful experience. I had the opportunity to do more writing and TV work, and to speak to businesses and schools. Although I enjoyed these different activities, I felt there was nothing competitive to focus on. I wanted to stay in shape so I could compete for an Olympic spot if that dream came back to me. So, I entered marathons and triathlons. That should have been enough, but I kept thinking about TV presenter Ben Fogle’s invitation: “Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?” I have always loved rowing and the feeling of the boat moving through the water. I started to miss that feeling, but I wasn’t ready to train every day. Still, I wanted some kind of competition. I asked some of my rowing friends if they wanted to join the race, but they weren’t very interested. I knew that if I entered the race, even though it was called an adventure, I would want to win. Would rowing with Ben give me the best chance to win? No. But part of me liked the idea of being an underdog with no pressure. I contacted Ben. He was going to enter the race anyway and had managed to gather the large entry fee and deposit for a boat, making the race a real possibility. We discussed the other costs; the boat and equipment would cost £70,000 – a lot of money. We believed we had a better chance than most, but it would still require effort to secure it. Besides the race costs, I also had to think about the loss of income from being away from home. Speaking at business conferences is one of the best ways to earn money as a retired athlete. It is nice that people are interested. However, I find it difficult to talk about my past achievements without having a new goal. Joining the race would mean I wouldn’t just be discussing my past; I would actually be doing something again: rowing across the Atlantic. I learned a lot while planning this adventure, but one of the biggest lessons was to appreciate the easy life of a full-time athlete. My preparation for the Olympics was hard, with my life focused on getting in the best shape; but looking back, it was quite simple. Yes, I trained almost every day, but the training program was organized, and there were doctors and dieticians. I was worried about how people would react to me racing with a TV presenter. I feared it would seem like I just wanted to be on TV, or else I would have chosen a better partner to win the race. However, my worries faded as we prepared. The Atlantic Rowing Race is about more than just rowing; it’s also about mental strength. Ben had completed the tough Marathon des Sables, spent time at sea, and lived on a deserted island for a year. However, he couldn’t row well. I was surprised by how little natural ability he had with a boat, and he was shocked by my lack of understanding. I could have been more patient, but I felt it was important to be honest with Ben about the big improvements he needed to make. I should have realized that this would be his level when I agreed to race with him.'

Text: 'Just over a year ago, I left my job to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle in northern Finland. At 26, I felt restless. I dreamed of cold, empty landscapes, perhaps because I was tired of the noise and crowds of London. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They agreed to hire me as a husky dog handler for a busy winter season. From December to February, they take many tourists on sled rides pulled by huskies across the ice and snow, for trips ranging from one hour to five days. They started with six dogs, but soon had more than 100. Recently, they took over a second property called the 'wilderness farm,’ which they described as a beautiful but basic place with unreliable electricity and no running water. They told me I could join the team for three months if I understood what I was getting into. 'The hours are long, the conditions are tough, and the work is very physical.’ I started packing right away. 

November 6, London: On my flight, I find myself staring at a page with over 100 pictures of huskies. I am supposed to memorize their names before I arrive, but I feel distracted and anxious. I put the page down and look out the window instead. It is said that spring moves north at about 26 km per day, bringing flowers and leaves. However, I see winter moving south, with rivers freezing over.

November 7, Helsinki and Hetta: The bus ride north is everything I hoped for. We drive through endless dark forests of thin conifer trees weighed down by snow, stopping occasionally for reindeer to cross. I arrive at the farm after dark, and as soon as I walk in, I am given a pair of boots and sent out into the cold. 'Do you want to be thrown in at the deep end?’ Anna asks. It’s a rhetorical question. I follow the sound of barking, which becomes a loud noise as I reach the dogsheds. Three people are running back and forth among the huskies, pulling them out and harnessing them to sleds. The dogs are very excited, straining against their ropes to get going. I can barely introduce myself, but the others are too busy to talk much. I stand on the sidelines and pet one of the quieter dogs. Someone gestures at me impatiently – 'Get in!’ – and I almost fall into the nearest sled. A command is shouted, and with a jerk, we are off into the dark, with only a headlamp for light.

November 15, Hetta: It doesn’t take long to become part of the husky guides, but first, I face a tough questioning about what I can contribute. 'Are you useful?’ Anna asks. I am confused. I don’t know. Am I? Further questions show that I am not: I have never driven a snowmobile, haven’t done woodwork since school, and have never chopped anything with an axe. 'You do have a driving license?’ someone asks finally. I nod, feeling relieved. The basics of dog-sledding are easy to learn: lean into the corners, put both feet on the brake to stop, and, no matter what, don’t let go of the handlebar. But everything else seems complicated. Simple tasks like feeding and watering the dogs become hard in freezing conditions. A bowl of water can freeze solid in front of you, so we must make a 'soup’ of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, my head is full of instructions, and my muscles ache from pulling heavy sleds – and from being pulled around by excited huskies. But I feel proud. 'I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw,’ I email my friends. 'In the snow.’'

Text: 'On that day, as Radcliffe ran past the finish line, reporters gathered to understand her amazing performance. It was noted that her time would qualify her to compete in the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Curious journalists asked her about the benefits of emu oil, a natural treatment recommended by Olympic gold medallist Cathy Freeman to heal injuries Radcliffe suffered when she accidentally collided with a bike during training. Radcliffe says that the achievement never really felt real to her. Looking back, she realizes it was a significant moment. However, she felt it was just what she was meant to do that day, so it didn’t feel overwhelming. She and her support team had decided not to set any limits on their goals. Their motto was: no limits. During the race, Gary Lough, Radcliffe's husband and coach, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio coverage. Next to him was Gerard Hartmann, her physiotherapist. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent wondered if she could maintain her fast pace, fearing it might cause her to drop out of the race. Hartmann was upset by this concern, although he acknowledged that anyone unaware of her fitness might see it as a risk to start so quickly. With 800 meters left, Radcliffe began to calculate her finish time. She realized she could finish in under 2 hours and 16 minutes if she crossed the line in less than three minutes. After running 41 kilometers at high speed, she managed to sprint the last distance in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, ‘I can run faster than that.’ She remembers the race director, Dave Bedford, saying he never thought anyone would come close to that time for a long time. Radcliffe thought, “I will come back and do it next year.” Unfortunately, that did not happen. After the race, everyone wanted to know how an athlete with such an unusual running style had beaten the skilled East African runners. Hartmann had spent weeks with Radcliffe, providing daily training sessions to support the 250-300 kilometers she ran each week. He said, ‘I’ve worked with 63 Olympic medallists, and no one on the treatment table could handle that level of pain. She would make me work harder than I made her work. I had to go deep into her muscles, and I would have to ice my thumbs afterward because I was in so much pain.’ Hartmann described traveling 13 hours from his home in Ireland to Radcliffe's training base in France, only to be greeted by her husband saying, ‘Gerard, you’re 15 minutes late, Paula’s waiting.’ There was no greeting or offer of tea. As soon as he arrived, she was ready for a two-hour training session. ‘Paula would push you to your limits. That’s what made her so good.’ During that time, Hartmann dedicated so much of his time to Radcliffe that his other athletes became frustrated. Can Radcliffe explain why no one has come close to her record? ‘Not really. I trained very hard, but there are more talented people out there. I thought it would happen with Mary Keitany (two-time London marathon winner). Maybe it’s because people are competing against each other instead of focusing on their own performance.’ What does she mean? ‘That mental attitude of never easing up, even when you’re winning, probably helped me because I never thought, “I can relax now.” It was always: “keep pushing as hard as you can.” Radcliffe did not realize it at the time, but that marathon was the peak of her career. She would never run that fast again. However, she left a lasting legacy, inspiring many women to take up long-distance running.'

Text: 'When my first cooking show, In Search of Perfection, was released, I was unsure how viewers and critics would react. There was a lot of discussion about a food ‘revolution’ happening in Britain, and I believed we had created a series that contributed something new to this movement. However, I worried whether people would appreciate a cooking style that included not just techniques but also history, nostalgia, and science. I watched the first episode feeling both excited and anxious. I needn’t have worried. The success of the show led to many other interesting projects, including a book based on my experiences at my restaurant. Each project felt like a journey, whether into the past, the mind, or cooking techniques. I then wrote several books in a series called ‘Perfection’, each linked to its own TV show. In these, the journey was often very physical, involving passports, suitcases, and travel plans. In Search of Total Perfection is the latest in the series, where you travel around the world to meet amazing artisans, like a man who finds joy in making golden pasta that tastes better than any other. These artisans have spent years pursuing their own ideas of perfection. Perfection is very subjective. Even the simple task of choosing which dishes to include in the series was challenging, and I knew I would disappoint many people by leaving out their favorites. I could imagine people asking, ‘Where’s steak and kidney pie and bread and butter pudding?’ However, after a long meeting with the TV production team, we finally created a list that would satisfy everyone. This experience reinforced my belief that each person has their own idea of perfection, shaped by personal emotions, memories, and environments. Despite the book’s title, I knew I wouldn’t claim that the recipes were ‘definitive’. I believed that by using my skills and knowledge, and by talking to food producers, artisans, chefs, and their customers, I could identify what made these dishes special. The dictionary defines ‘perfection’ as being perfect, but it also means improving through constant experimentation—trying ideas and refining them until something unique is created. The TV series allowed me to explore various foods, people, and places I had never seen in any restaurant, and I was excited to delve into memory and nostalgia in food, as I started my career in a similar way. Finding the best ingredients took me around the world. Among my experiences were visiting a canning factory that was processing the wrong type of tomato and a dairy farm that did not meet our standards for perfection, which forced us to stop filming there! While refining each recipe, I ended up hand-milking a cow and using dry ice to make ice cream, cooking chicken breasts in a hospital scanning machine, and almost burning my house down trying to heat the oven enough for a proper Neapolitan-style pizza.'

Text: 'We were still a long way from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise, swerved off the road into a field, and stopped. John got out and opened the hood. He looked at the engine for a long time with his hands in his pockets, looking serious. “Actually, I have no idea what I’m doing,” he finally said, and he and Mum started to laugh. Bea was worried, “We can’t stay here forever,” she said. The field went on for miles. There was not much in it, just grass and many flowers, like poppies and daisies. “No, we can’t stay here forever,” I agreed, because it was best to support Bea. We got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We sat by the road and watched John get smaller as he walked away to find someone who knew about cars. Mum lay down on the grass. “Tell us a story,” she said. Bea lay down next to her. “Go on, tell us a story.” So I told them about how the day before we left London, I heard two birds talking. I shared everything they talked about: breadcrumbs, other birds, the weather, and an argument over a worm. “That’s silly, no one understands bird language,” Bea said. My eyes felt wet. “I do.” But I didn’t sound very sure. “Liar.” I felt embarrassed. How could I be lying if I remembered every word? The more I thought about it, the less sure I became. “Mum…?” But she had fallen asleep in the sun. John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped us push the van down the road to the hotel. Bea didn’t want to get out. The boys didn’t mind at all. They waved and smiled at her through the back windows. We followed John into a café. It was set back from the road and not far from where our van was parked. “It’s a hotel,” John whispered. “I think it might be a bit expensive.” “We’ll just have some tea,” Mum said, and we sat down in the shade. The tea they brought was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum looked into the pot. “It’s like syrup in there,” she said. We stayed at the café all day while John looked sadly at the engine. “I guess it’s a miracle it got us this far,” he said as it started to get dark. Mum took blankets out onto the road. She made a bed for us in the hotel garden. It felt nice to sleep on the ground. “I’ll have to get us towed into Marrakech,” John said from the other side of Mum. Half an hour later, we were in a truck watching our van being pulled behind with John driving. At first, Bea didn’t want to move, so John picked her up and put her in the truck. Now she sat in the front with the driver. I kept wondering how we would get home now that our van had to be towed everywhere. I thought it might be easier to take a boat straight to London. Then I must have fallen asleep.'

Text: 'Lucy was talking at the welcome party in the hotel ballroom to two other pianists who were also at the Prague Classical Music Festival. Unlike her, they were not competing: a guy from Tokyo and a girl from a European city whose name Lucy didn’t quite catch over the noise, maybe Liesel or Louisa. They were both about ten years older than she was and spoke good English. They discussed the pieces they were playing, their recent travels, and their future plans. “I think I'm doing Tanglewood this summer,” Lucy told them. It sounded impressive, but she didn’t really want to go to the Tanglewood festival. She often felt overwhelmed by the concerts and competitions that took her around the world, making her miss so much school that she wasn’t officially enrolled anymore. Instead, she worked with various tutors from the University of San Francisco. She hadn’t even wanted to come to the Prague Festival, which selected only fifteen pianists her age from around the world. Out of thousands of applicants, she had been chosen. There had been a celebration. Lucy’s dad bought her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant to congratulate her, and her little brother Gus dreamed of being at the same festival one day. Grace Chang, her teacher, took Lucy out for a special dinner to plan her repertoire. The truth was, Lucy hadn’t even applied. Her mother had filled out the form and sent in the CD. “I didn't want you to be disappointed if you didn’t get in,” her mom had said. Lucy thought, more like you didn’t want to give me the chance to say no. Back then, she believed that causing trouble was the worst thing a person could do, and she didn’t even think about trying to get out of it. The guy from Tokyo leaned forward as if he had misheard her. “Tanglewood?” “Yeah.” “How old are you?” “Fifteen.” He exchanged a look with Liesel/Louisa, who said, “Wow.” Lucy hadn’t meant to brag. It was hard to know when sharing her achievements was just fitting in or showing off. “It's just part of this new youth-spotlight thing they're trying...” “Excuse me,” Liesel/Louisa said, looking across the room as if she saw someone she needed to talk to. The guy from Tokyo stayed. “Have you ever been to Japan?” He had long, shaggy hair, like many male musicians, to show they were music nerds but also cool. “Once. When I was about eight.” He started to reply when Lucy's grandfather appeared at her side. “Lucy, let me introduce you to someone.” He took her arm and pulled her away from the conversation. “And don’t get too friendly with the competition.” “They're not the competition.” “Everyone is the competition.” Her grandfather took her around the room and made her talk to everyone he thought was important. Lucy smiled and nodded a lot, understanding only part of what was said. In the elevator to their suite after leaving the party, her grandfather turned to her. “You did well in there, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and there’s a buzz about you. They all know who you are.” She liked that part. Being someone important. Even if it meant some people were jealous or thought she was too young for the attention she received. Being a concert pianist didn’t earn her any special respect from the kids she had gone to school with. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn’t know and wouldn’t care that she could play a Rachmaninov allegro perfectly. But in places like this, she felt she mattered.'

Text: "‘Spending too much time online isn’t good for you. You should go out into the real world,’ said Dad. It’s hard to argue with him, so I decided to look into what experts say about this – and it’s quite interesting. Research shows that most teenagers who use social media have many real-life friends, a strong sense of identity, and are learning important technical skills for the digital world. Simon Miles, an e-safety expert, says ‘social networking is now a key part of growing up. Teenagers don’t just use media like adults do – they live in it. This isn’t necessarily good or bad – it depends on how you use it.’ 

How does our social networking compare to what our parents did when they were young? Jim Matthews, a social media analyst, says it’s ‘like the modern version of hanging out at the youth club, where parents used to share jokes and gossip: a kind of virtual youth club.’ He believes it helps teenagers build their identity away from their parents and learn to handle teenage issues and interact with their peers. 

Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson says: ‘Adolescence is a time for figuring out who you are. Social networking can help with this: you can share your favorite music or sports, find out what you enjoy, and see that others have different perspectives. Research shows that active social networkers are not as self-centered as those who don’t use social media.’ He adds that social media can be helpful for shy people: ‘Talking online can be easier than in person, and it allows you to practice social skills in a less stressful way.’ 

Professor Andrew Phillips is studying how young people use social networking sites. He believes they can help quiet individuals with specific interests connect with others who share those interests. ‘If you’re one of only a few people in your school who likes a certain type of music, you might feel alone. But if you find a social networking group of similar people, you can feel more connected and popular in a different way,’ he says. 

Pauline White, a digital education expert, shared something interesting: ‘Young people who find new interests online, join networks of like-minded individuals, and create their own content are truly making the most of social networks.’ She believes social networking is becoming a creative outlet: teenagers are making videos, podcasts, and blogs about their interests. Photo-sharing sites are changing creativity, allowing photographers to connect, learn, share images, and deepen their skills. ‘This all helps with job prospects and will be useful in the workplace,’ she says. ‘Every business uses social media to sell and build brand awareness – and you need to know how it works to attract customers. For example, if you create a product and have 1000 friends on different social networks, they could all be potential customers. If you connect all those networks, you have your customer base.’ 

Teenagers who use social networking creatively will benefit when they become adults and enter the job market, agrees Matthews. ‘One great thing about many sites is the chance to work with others to create and share content. Collaboration is an important skill in the 21st century and is essential for being employable in a digital world.’"

Text: 'When people think of a relaxing family vacation, a long trip across nine western states in the US and a Canadian province might not be the first idea. However, my parents were not looking for a quiet getaway when they planned our summer vacation this year. My dad seemed determined to create what he thought was the ultimate family bonding experience. “Not enough people do this anymore,” he and my mother said repeatedly in the weeks before our trip, while my twin brother and I exchanged worried looks, thinking, “There are probably good reasons for that!” 

In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, coolers, and a mix of clothes for any weather. I was excited but knew I would miss my privacy for the next two weeks, although I had some coping strategies ready. With barely enough space left for us in the car, we began “The Family Great American Road Trip.” Leaving our spacious home for smaller places for the next five thousand miles, I wasn’t the only one wondering what we had gotten ourselves into. 

We headed west through the Oklahoma panhandle. Even though we were still close to home, we had our share of adventures. We stopped for the night near a town in Oklahoma, under a sky full of stars, after almost being blown off the highway by a dust storm. We quickly learned that cattle have the right-of-way on the road! The next day, we woke up early and continued our journey. I noticed a pattern: desert landscapes changed to mountains. The days started to blend together, but each adventure was still unique. We left our footprints in the Great Sand Dunes and then moved on to Pagosa Springs, Colorado. The strong smell of sulfur in that friendly tourist town hinted at what we would experience later. 

At one point, as we climbed to our next destination, we realized that roads marked for Jeeps were best for Jeep drivers. The mix of old and new was visible everywhere we stopped. Dealing with construction traffic became normal. Disappointment turned to laughter when we took pictures by the huge “CLOSED” signs at the Four Corners Monument. We passed many wind farms on our way to Yellowstone National Park, where we watched the sunset over bear habitats near the roads. ‘Bear jams,’ managed by park volunteers, were common as traffic would stop to let bears cross. Our own close encounter with a bear on the road (and a nervous park ranger) gave us unforgettable memories.
