As we continued driving, life back home faded away, and even the hotel we stayed in, with its problems, couldn’t dampen our excitement. It was an old, creaky building with no internet or cell phone service, but the views were amazing. After watching a rainstorm from our hotel in Canada, my family and I began our journey back south. My parents were right: you don’t need to travel to a faraway place to find something special. It was a bit sad to be home together again, but at least I hadn’t argued with my brother during our one hundred hours on the road! We had three thousand photos from our adventure to look through and remember. I knew that the moments I would cherish most would be the unexpected and spontaneous ones.'

Text: 'Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating for two years. Her father, Jeff, had a job overseas, and her mother, Dahlia, would join him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, were staying in England. Amy would spend the next year finishing her final school courses, living under the care of the college Head. It was her last year at school, so it would have been unfair for Amy to move. Amy was happy because she had the best room at the college, with its own kitchen and study area. She also had free access to the Internet and phone. Jeff and Dahlia would keep an eye on Amy, whether she liked it or not. So, Rose was moving to her grandmother’s house. Rose only had vague memories of her grandmother from holidays, and she had never known her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, her parents were not excited about it, but Daisy insisted it was no trouble and was eager to reconnect with her granddaughter. Rose was unsure why her parents did not get along with her grandma, but there had been a disagreement in the past, leading to summers spent away from the only other family member she knew. Rose had been ten years old when she last said goodbye, but her memories were happy. Dahlia said living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy was very social and had a talent for bringing people together. Within a week, Rose could expect dinner invitations, coffee mornings, and shopping trips. The thought made Rose smile. Her grandmother was not a typical frail old lady; in fact, Daisy seemed to attend more social events than anyone else. Before the move, Dahlia and Rose had a 'talk.' Rose was sensible and mature for her age. She knew about healthy eating, staying fit, and getting enough sleep. But this time, Rose insisted on one thing: she wanted her independence. Living with Daisy would meet her needs, but Rose wanted to play music loudly, invite friends over, or go out without asking for permission every time. Surely she could be trusted with these small things now? She didn’t want to be nagged about homework or staying out late, and most of all, she didn’t want to be dragged around by her grandmother. Daisy understood. Rose’s mother had given her a new touch-screen mobile phone with a video camera for emergencies only, as Dahlia insisted. Rose was thrilled. They all agreed that it would be about trust from now on. Daisy would trust Rose to act maturely, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too controlling. If either of them crossed the line, they would talk about it again. Rose had never been a wild child. Her few school friends were similar, so her school reports were always good, and her exam results were excellent. This had worked in her favor. In five weeks, Rose would start at a new school, meet new friends, form bonds, and begin her life again. It was her fourth senior school in five years, so she felt experienced. At least she knew this was the last time, as she would be starting her final two years at school. For Rose, it was a new moment in her life, a new piece in the puzzle that was her life.'

Charlotte Grainger shares that her primary school teacher was the first person to think she might write a novel. “I believed that writing a book would be a great achievement because it seemed challenging, and I didn’t know what other teenagers were doing, like competing in the Olympics. When I turned 13, I thought, ‘I might as well try this now.’ The novel she started at that age is now about to be published. “I recently told my former teacher about it, and she was surprised. She thought I would probably write a book when I was 30 or 40. I never considered that – I didn’t understand why I should wait to do something I might be good at.”

It is a winter afternoon in the offices of Charlotte’s publishers. Even though I knew I was going to interview a 15-year-old girl about her book, I was still surprised to see a teenager sitting there. The book is a significant achievement: the story is confident and exciting. Nothing about it, except for the age of its main character, suggests it was written by a teenager. A public relations representative is with us in case Charlotte needs support, but she doesn’t. She is independent, spirited, with a bright face and sharp intelligence, but also a calmness that keeps her from being overly confident. Charlotte recognizes the limits of her youth. When I ask her about the complex moral issues in her book, she says, “I was trying to ask big questions, not answer them. I don’t have many life lessons to share with my readers,” she laughs. “I don’t think my age limits my understanding of the world, but I also don’t think I’m particularly wise. I was just interested in exploring the idea of taking responsibility.”

Charlotte has a theory about teenagers and how they are often misrepresented in fiction aimed at them. She believes there are three types of teenagers shown in novels: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows little about the world, and the socially awkward teenager. Reading about these character types frustrated her. “What if you’re basically fine? There aren’t many stories about characters who aren’t flawed in some way. The message some writers send – and I don’t think it’s intentional – is that teenagers can’t know who they are because they lack experience. This can hurt their self-confidence.”

Charlotte has always enjoyed reading famous fantasy authors, some of whom you might think inspired her, but they almost discouraged her from writing. “Books by my favorite fantasy authors explore deep psychological and life themes. I wondered: is this what I need to do to write a good book, and am I capable of it?” However, she appreciates the influence of a book called How Not to Write a Novel. “It explains that if the reader starts to guess what will happen, the suspense is probably gone.”

It might be easy to say that Charlotte’s parents, both journalists, played a key role in getting her novel published. In fact, her father’s connection in publishing was what led to her book being read initially. She recognizes her good luck, as getting anyone to read a first novel is difficult, regardless of the author’s age. “Every aspiring writer needs support and a bit of luck, but after that, you’re on your own. Ultimately, writers succeed or fail based on their talent, so I don’t take anything for granted,” Charlotte concludes.

Text: "‘Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,’ said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then one guy, David, who had some experience with freestyle ski-jumping, stepped forward and skied down the slope towards the jump. He hit the ramp quickly and flew upwards, arms waving in the air. Even to our untrained eyes, something seemed wrong. We held our breath. He landed hard, losing both skis, and flipped head-first into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth kindly told us, ‘speed can be unpredictable.’ Maybe I wasn’t meant for this freestyle skiing. On past skiing holidays, I had enjoyed practicing turns in the snow. I wasn’t one of those teenagers who did freestyle tricks in skate parks. I thought it looked fun, but I felt that if I tried to join the skateboarders, I would be laughed at. Then my parents decided we would have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training center in the US. It had a large indoor facility near the slopes, with trampolines and ski jumps covered in artificial snow. Students practiced their tricks and landed in foam pits – not a realistic introduction to what awaited us on the slopes. After practicing indoors, students went outside to try their moves for real. ‘Progression is inevitable!’ the center’s slogan cheerfully promised. ‘Before places like this trained people, inexperienced ski jumpers would just throw themselves down the slopes and hope for the best,’ said Gareth. ‘But remember – if you land on the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.’ The ‘knuckle’ is the flat area behind the jump before the slope steepens into the landing zone. If you land in the zone, you keep moving forward, which reduces impact. If you land on the flat, you stop suddenly, which hurts. So, speed is important. At first, it was hard to convince my body to ignore what my brain was telling me and to go straight towards the jump. My legs would almost go backward as I neared the launch point, so I landed hard on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday I felt exhausted. ‘You need to control the jump, not let it control you,’ said Gareth. Day two started on the trampolines. I thought I would hate being indoors, looking at the snowy mountains outside, but bouncing on the trampolines was fun. Some drills copied moves we would make while ski-jumping, while others taught us ‘aerial awareness’ – knowing what your body was doing as you spun in the air. Gareth gave us a running commentary. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed improvement – every time I tried, I was aware of the moment before take-off, and then I found myself lying in the foam cubes next to the trampoline. We returned to the mountain to try again. There were more setbacks before I finally landed properly. Gareth seemed as happy as I was, and for a moment I felt proud of achieving such a difficult goal. But that feeling didn’t last long. On the last run of the day, I forced myself to keep my speed up as I approached the jump, became airborne, and landed correctly in the landing zone. Then I noticed both skis sliding down the slope ahead, no longer attached to my feet."

Text: 'Imagine you are on a rollercoaster at an amusement park. Your palms are sweaty with fear, and your nails are digging into the safety harness. Suddenly, the ride stops, and you take a deep breath as the carriage slowly moves upwards. There is a pause, then a sudden drop that makes your stomach feel like it is in the air. With your teeth clenched, you rush forward, turn sharply to the left, and then go upside down. Your senses are overwhelmed, and you let out a scream of fear. But you have only yourself to blame: like millions of others each year, you chose to pay to enter the theme park. 

What is surprising to me is that amusement parks, with their thrilling rides designed to attract crowds, are a massive industry. To provide the excitement and escape from reality that visitors want, there are large teams of creative engineers, designers, and marketing experts working behind the scenes. The idea of being a 'rollercoaster designer' might sound like a childhood dream, but it is a significant challenge. Designers must create a perfect mix of fun and fear while ensuring that riders are safe. They also need to introduce new elements to keep visitors interested. 

While many people think that rollercoasters have become more intense over time, most of the techniques used today, like the wheels that allow rides to go upside down, were actually invented by US designer John Miller in the early 20th century. During his 'golden age' of rollercoasters, many extreme designs were tested, often to the discomfort of riders. Now, however, designers must work within the limits set by specialized ride manufacturers. 

I spoke to three experts about rollercoasters. Professor Brendan Walker, a 'thrill engineer' with a background in aeronautics, said, 'The skill is in putting the pieces together.' Dr. John Roberts, a fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering, explained that this means 'quickly switching between feelings of excitement and safety, so people feel like they are being thrown around but are still safe.' 

To create an amazing ride, the teams behind rollercoasters must develop a strong story, whether it is a space adventure or a fast-paced jungle chase, that works with any new features, like the tallest drops or the most twists, to create a smooth experience. However, Professor Walker noted that, like in many creative fields, intuition, experience, and trial-and-error are crucial. Jeff Hornick, a senior director of theme park development, agreed, saying, 'It helps to be a thrill-seeker when designing rollercoasters to understand what riders want and to test the rides before they open to the public.' 

I asked the experts if rollercoaster designers would need to adopt new technologies, like virtual reality, as technology changes many industries. Walker responded that we should not expect too much. 'Virtual reality can add a layer of excitement, but it is similar to how old rollercoasters were beautifully painted,' he said. 'New technology appears all the time, and parks quickly adopt it because it is exciting and can enhance the ride experience. But the physical experience of the coaster will remain the most important aspect for many years to come.'

At 25, Miranda Ellington has already accomplished a lot as a choreographer, creating works for many theatres and dance companies. She also dances occasionally. I wonder why she manages to do both activities in her busy life. “Dancing again reminds me of what it’s like to be in the studio, following the instructions of demanding choreographers, and how stressful that can be. Choreographers can forget what it’s like to rehearse all day,” she explains. As a choreographer, she takes on a teaching role and enjoys working with young students. “A beginner dancer is often open to trying new ideas. In some ways, working with students is easier than with professionals because they are willing to take risks. They want to succeed, but they don’t yet fully understand their strengths and weaknesses. This lack of a complete picture helps them accept even tough criticism. However, they might still question what I say, and when they do, I appreciate their honest feedback.” 

When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, and the music guides her actions. “There may be music I don’t like, but I still make sure to create the best dance routine for it. If dancers don’t respond well to a certain piece of music, it can be frustrating, but I still need to find solutions. This doesn’t mean I will choose a new piece of music. Ideally, I would like to be more experimental and have the option to switch to different pieces – it would definitely help improve the mood during tough rehearsals. Unfortunately, I’m often working on large productions where the music has already been decided by the composer and cannot be changed.” 

Miranda does not believe in sticking to one institution. “I think it’s important to keep meeting new people. However, I must remember that the theatres and schools I work with have very different methods and styles. So, I need to be ready to adapt my approach each time I go somewhere new, rather than just doing the same thing everywhere. This helps me avoid becoming too set in my ways.” 

The conversation shifts to a recent documentary about professional ballet dancers and choreographers. “There have been glamorous documentaries in the past that were misleading,” Miranda says. “This one really tries to show an accurate picture of life in a dance company. There was a scene where a young dancer receives many corrections, and I smiled in recognition. She knows she’s not getting it right but can’t make her body do what’s needed. It’s hard to watch but very real. The public often underestimates the amount of work and dedication required in ballet.” 

I ask Miranda what makes a great ballet or dance production. “It’s when everything the company has put in – the music, costumes, lighting, and dancers – comes together. Perfection might be too much to expect, but aiming high is appreciated by audiences and can allow for a few artistic mistakes. I’ve been part of productions where the dance steps are excellent, but something about the costumes or props is distracting, and that’s disappointing.” 

Miranda has done a wide range of work, so I wonder how she sees herself: is she a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist? “People often want to label you, and I don’t quite understand that. There’s also a modern trend to encourage expertise in a narrow area. I don’t really agree with that, although there may come a time when I’m happy to be known for one thing. For now, I just want to expand my horizons.”

Text: 'A friend once asked me why I travel when I can see everything on television. I agreed that you can see amazing things on TV, but why stay at home on your sofa when there is so much to experience outside? This conversation inspired my unusual four-day trip and a film that encourages people to turn off their TVs. A friend was getting rid of his old sofa, which became the main focus of the film. I added three wheels and some cables to it and connected them to old seatbelts over my shoulders. I placed my luggage on the sofa and slept on it each night, including one night on the beach. Several friends joined me, helping to pull the sofa and motivating me to keep going. I have gone on many walking trips in recent years, but this was something completely different. It was the longest distance I have ever walked, and I walked on main roads, which allowed me to stop at roadside cafés and relax on the sofa with a cappuccino instead of eating sandwiches while sitting on a rock. I often had to tell people, “No, I’m not doing this for charity, and I’m not training for a marathon.” When someone at work asks about my weekend, I prefer to share how I dragged a sofa 100 miles across southern England rather than talk about the latest TV show. You can watch the film on my website.'

Text: 'When I read about guided swimming trips in the sea around some small Greek islands, I felt excited. I had never tried organized group trips before. My brother, who I had traveled with before, was busy, so I thought a group holiday might be a good idea. The man at the Greek port looked curious when I asked for a single ferry ticket, as the islands are popular with families. I explained that I wouldn’t be alone for long; I would be joining ten others to swim around the small islands. Although he still looked puzzled, he smiled and showed me on board. Our group had exchanged emails before we left, but there was little time to talk before our first group swim. Our guides explained that a support boat would follow us the whole time and made sure we knew how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, and then it was time for our first proper 1.5 km swim, which made me nervous. I had trained in my local pool and done some river swimming, but I had never swum long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger, and I found myself at the back of the slow group, which was not where I wanted to be. I watched the faster swimmers move ahead like dolphins. I wanted to finish this first distance, though, and I was happy when I finally did it on my own. The next days followed a routine: jumping in, finding a comfortable speed, and stopping to enjoy the scenery. As the swims became longer, my speed and enjoyment also increased. I felt less need for the support boat. I can hardly wait to come back next year.'

Text: "Being a flight attendant is not easy, but since I started this job, I have traveled to many places, from the US to Australia. I work with amazing people, have plenty of time off, and my life is always interesting, which makes it a great job for someone young like me! As a child, I went to a boarding school far from my family, so I often flew alone at the beginning and end of each term. When I felt lonely, I would ask the flight attendants if I could help serve meals to passengers, and some of them let me. This experience stayed with me when I wanted to leave my banking job and look for a new path. At the interview, there were many young people, and many were hired. They were often well-qualified like me and were changing careers. Before the interview, I practiced what to say, focusing on my strengths and past work experience, rather than just saying I loved to travel, which everyone else would say. This approach helped me get the job! I would recommend this work to anyone because there are many rewarding aspects, though the free flights are not the main reason. Most airline staff work very hard, and there is a saying: 'no one is finished until everyone is finished.' It feels like a big family; even if we don’t see each other often, we are still close. When I’m not working, I don’t have to take work home with me. If I do encounter difficult passengers, which is rare, I know the flight will end soon, and I probably won’t see them again!"

Text: 'Rock the Planet is a musical show where the actors also need to be good musicians. It opened in London last year after five years in the USA, where it won the title of ‘Best Musical’ four times! However, putting on the show with an all-British cast was challenging. The UK has stricter rules about how many performances young actors can do each week compared to the USA, where they can perform more often. Because of this, they needed twice as many actors in the UK. Fortunately, the director found many talented actors based in the UK, and they have just won their first ‘Best Musical’ award. 

The theatre in London is larger than the one in the USA, and it has been full every night, with audiences eager to hear the songs that became popular in America. I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, ‘It’s amazing that I get paid to play, especially with a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar.’ He shared how busy the young actors are. ‘We have regular school lessons each day at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends.’ I asked him what his classmates thought of the show. ‘My whole class came! The theatre offers special ticket deals for schools. They loved it, which made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it’s expensive for them,’ he explained. 

When I mentioned that I also play guitar, Jamie found a spare one and invited me to play with him and the other young actors. We played a song called Days, which I didn’t know. Jamie helped me learn it, and I felt proud when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s talent and wished I had similar skills. I was just trying to keep up and was relieved that the show’s director wasn’t there to hear my mistakes! Although the young actors were already musicians, with some playing multiple instruments, none had played in a band before. Luckily, they found it quite easy. Jamie admitted that the hardest part was looking natural when they first performed together. They were so focused that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it is definitely worth seeing.'
